SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I thought the King had more affected the
Duke of Albany, then Cornwall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: It did alwayes ſeeme ſo to vs: But now in the diuision of the Kingdome, it ap-peares not which of the Dukes hee valewes mo’t, for qualities are ſo weigh’d, that curiosity in nei-ther, can make choise of eithers moity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not this your Son, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: His breeding Sir, hath bin at my charge. I haue ſo often blush’d to acknowledge him, that now I am braz’d too't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot conceiue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, this yong Fellowes mother could; where-vpon ſhe grew round womb’d, and had indeede (Sir) a Sonne for her Cradle, ere ſhe had a husband for her bed. Do you ſmell a fault?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot wish the fault vndone, the iſſue of it, being ſo proper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: But I haue a Sonne, Sir, by order of Law, ſome yeere elder then this; who, yet is no deerer in my ac-count, though this Knaue came ſomthing ſawcily to the world before he was ſent for: yet was his Mother fayre, there was good ſport at his making, and the horson must be acknowledged. Doe you know this Noble Gentle-man, Edmond?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edm.
SPEECH.LINE: No, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord of Kent:
Remember him heereafter, as my Honourable Friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edm.
SPEECH.LINE: My ſeruices to your Lordship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I must loue you, and ſue to know you better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edm.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I ſhall ſtudy deseruing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath bin out nine yeares, and away he ſhall againe. The King is comming.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Sennet. Enter King Lear, Cornwall, Albany, Gonerill, Re-gan, Cordelia, and attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Attend the Lords of France & Burgundy, Gloster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: [I ſhall, my Lord. ]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Meane time we ſhal expreſſe our darker purpose.
Giue me the Map there. Know, that we haue diuided
In three our Kingdome: and ‘tis our fast intent,
To ſhake all Cares and Busineſſe from our Age,
Conferring them on yonger ſtrengths, while we
Vnburthen’d crawle toward death. Our ſon of Cornwal,
And you our no leſſe louing Sonne of Albany,
We haue this houre a constant will to publish
Our daughters ſeuerall Dowers, that future ſtrife
May be preuented now. The Princes, France & Burgundy,
Great Riuals in our yongest daughters loue,
Long in our Court, haue made their amorous ſoiourne,
And heere are to be anſwer’d. Tell me my daughters
(Since now we will diuest vs both of Rule,
Interest of Territory, Cares of State)
Which of you ſhall we ſay doth loue vs mo’t,
That we, our largest bountie may extend
Where Nature doth with merit challenge. Gonerill,
Our eldest borne, ſpeake first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I loue you more then word can weild y matter,
Deerer then eye-ſight, ſpace, and libertie,
Beyond what can be valewed, rich or rare,
No leſſe then life, with grace, health, beauty, honor:
As much as Childe ere lou’d, or Father found.
A loue that makes breath poore, and ſpeech vnable,
Beyond all manner of ſo much I loue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall Cordelia ſpeake? Loue, and be ſilent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Of all these bounds euen from this Line, to this,
With ſhadowie Forrests, and with Champains rich’d
With plenteous Riuers, and wide-skirted Meades
We make thee Lady. To thine and Albanies iſſues
Be this perpetuall. What ſayes our ſecond Daughter?
Our deerest Regan, wife of Cornwall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I am made of that ſelfe-mettle as my Sister,
And prize me at her worth. In my true heart,
I finde ſhe names my very deede of loue:
Onely ſhe comes too ſhort, that I profeſſe
My ſelfe an enemy to all other ioyes,
Which the mo’t precious ſquare of ſense profeſſes,
And finde I am alone felicitate
In your deere Highneſſe loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Then poore Cordelia,
And yet not ſo, ſince I am ſure my loue's
More ponderous then my tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: To thee, and thine hereditarie euer,
Remaine this ample third of our faire Kingdome,
No leſſe in ſpace, validitie, and pleasure
Then that conferr’d on Gonerill. Now our Ioy,
Although our last and least; to whose yong loue,
The Vines of France, and Milke of Burgundie,
Striue to be interest. What can you ſay, to draw
A third, more opilent then your Sisters? ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing will come of nothing, ſpeake againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnhappie that I am, I cannot heaue
My heart into my mouth: I loue your Maiesty
According to my bond, no more nor leſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: How, how Cordelia? Mend your ſpeech a little,
Least you may marre your Fortunes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord,
You haue begot me, bred me, lou’d me.
I returne those duties backe as are right fit,
Obey you, Loue you, and mo’t Honour you.
Why haue my Sisters Husbands, if they ſay
They loue you all? Happily when I ſhall wed,
That Lord, whose hand must take my plight, ſhall carry
Halfe my loue with him, halfe my Care, and Dutie,
Sure I ſhall neuer marry like my Sisters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: But goes thy heart with this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: So young, and ſo vntender?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: So young my Lord, and true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be ſo, thy truth then be thy dowre:
For by the ſacred radience of the Sunne,
The misteries of Heccat and the night:
By all the operation of the Orbes,
From whom we do exist, and cease to be,
Heere I disclaime all my Paternall care,
Propinquity and property of blood,
And as a ſtranger to my heart and me,
Hold thee from this for euer. The barbarous Scythian,
Or he that makes his generation meſſes
To gorge his appetite, ſhall to my bosome
Be as well neighbour’d, pittied, and releeu’d,
As thou my ſometime Daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Liege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace Kent,
Come not betweene the Dragon and his wrath,
I lou’d her mo’t, and thought to ſet my rest
On her kind nursery. Hence and avoid my ſight:
So be my graue my peace, as here I giue
Her Fathers heart from her; call France, who ſtirres?
Call Burgundy, Cornwall, and Albanie,
With my two Daughters Dowres, digest the third,
Let pride, which ſhe cals plainneſſe, marry her:
I doe inuest you ioyntly with my power,
Preheminence, and all the large effects
That troope with Maiesty. Our ſelfe by Monthly course,
With reseruation of an hundred Knights,
By you to be ſustain’d, ſhall our abode
Make with you by due turne, onely we ſhall retaine
The name, and all th’ addition to a King: the Sway,
Reuennew, Execution of the rest,
Beloued Sonnes be yours, which to confirme,
This Coronet part betweene you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Royall Lear,
Whom I haue euer honor’d as my King,
Lou’d as my Father, as my Master follow’d,
As my great Patron thought on in my praiers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Le.
SPEECH.LINE: The bow is bent & drawne, make from the ſhaft.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it fall rather, though the forke inuade
The region of my heart, be Kent vnmannerly,
When Lear is mad, what wouldest thou do old man?
Think'st thou that dutie ſhall haue dread to ſpeake,
When power to flattery bowes?
To plainneſſe honour's bound,
When Maiesty falls to folly, reserue thy ſtate,
And in thy best consideration checke
This hideous rashneſſe, answere my life, my iudgement:
Thy yongest Daughter do's not loue thee least,
Nor are those empty hearted, whose low ſounds
Reuerbe no hollowneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Kent, on thy life no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: My life I neuer held but as pawne
To wage against thine enemies, nere feare to loose it,
Thy ſafety being motiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Out of my ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: See better Lear, and let me ſtill remaine
The true blanke of thine eie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by Apollo,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by Apollo, King
Thou ſwear'st thy Gods in vaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: O Vaſſall! Miscreant.
Alb. Cor.
Deare Sir forbeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Kill thy Physition, and thy fee bestow
Vpon the foule disease, reuoke thy guift,
Or whil'st I can vent clamour from my throate,
Ile tell thee thou dost euill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lea.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me recreant, on thine allegeance heare me;
That thou hast ſought to make vs breake our vowes,
Which we durst neuer yet; and with ſtrain’d pride,
To come betwixt our ſentences, and our power,
Which, nor our nature, nor our place can beare;
Our potencie made good, take thy reward.
Fiue dayes we do allot thee for prouision,
To ſhield thee from disasters of the world,
And on the ſixt to turne thy hated backe
Vpon our kingdome: if on the tenth day following,
Thy banisht trunke be found in our Dominions,
The moment is thy death, away. By Iupiter,
This ſhall not be reuok’d,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare thee well King, ſith thus thou wilt appeare,
Freedome liues hence, and banishment is here;
The Gods to their deere ſhelter take thee Maid,
That iustly think'st, and hast mo’t rightly ſaid:
And your large ſpeeches, may your deeds approue,
That good effects may ſpring from words of loue:
Thus Kent, O Princes, bids you all adew,
Hee'l ſhape his old course, in a Country new.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter Gloster with France, and Bur-gundy, Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere's France and Burgundy, my Noble Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord of Burgundie,
We first addreſſe toward you, who with this King
Hath riuald for our Daughter; what in the least
Will you require in present Dower with her,
Or cease your quest of Loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bur.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t Royall Maiesty,
I craue no more then hath your Highneſſe offer’d,
Nor will you tender leſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Right Noble Burgundy,
When ſhe was deare to vs, we did hold her ſo,
But now her price is fallen: Sir, there ſhe ſtands,
If ought within that little ſeeming ſubstance,
Or all of it with our displeasure piec’d,
And nothing more may fitly like your Grace,
Shee's there, and ſhe is yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bur.
SPEECH.LINE: I know no anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you with those infirmities ſhe owes,
Vnfriended, new adopted to our hate,
Dow'rd with our curse, and ſtranger’d with our oath,
Take her or, leaue her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bur.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me Royall Sir,
Election makes not vp in ſuch conditions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Le.
SPEECH.LINE: Then leaue her ſir, for by the powre that made me,
I tell you all her wealth. For you great King,
I would not from your loue make ſuch a ſtray,
To match you where I hate, therefore beseech you
T' auert your liking a more worthier way,
Then on a wretch whom Nature is asham’d
Almost t’ acknowledge hers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fra.
SPEECH.LINE: This is mo’t ſtrange,
That ſhe whom euen but now, was your obiect,
The argument of your praise, balme of your age,
The best, the deerest, ſhould in this trice of time
Commit a thing ſo monstrous, to dismantle
So many folds of fauour: ſure her offence
Must be of ſuch vnnaturall degree,
That monsters it: Or your fore-voucht affection
Fall into taint, which to beleeue of her
Must be a faith that reason without miracle
Should neuer plant in me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: I yet beseech your Maiesty.
If for I want that glib and oylie Art,
To ſpeake and purpose not, ſince what I will intend,
Ile do't before I ſpeake, that you make knowne
It is no vicious blot, murther, or fouleneſſe,
No vnchaste action or dishonoured ſtep
That hath depriu’d me of your Grace and fauour,
But euen for want of that, for which I am richer,
A ſtill ſoliciting eye, and ſuch a tongue,
That I am glad I haue not, though not to haue it,
Hath lost me in your liking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Better thou had'st
Not beene borne, then not t'haue pleas’d me better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fra.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it but this? A tardineſſe in nature,
Which often leaues the history vnspoke
That it intends to do: my Lord of Burgundy,
What ſay you to the Lady? Loue's not loue
When it is mingled with regards, that ſtands
Aloofe from th’ intire point, will you haue her?
She is herselfe a Dowrie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bur.
SPEECH.LINE: Royall King,
Giue but that portion which your ſelfe propos’d,
And here I take Cordelia by the hand,
Dutcheſſe of Burgundie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing, I haue ſworne, I am firme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bur.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorry then you haue ſo lost a Father,
That you must loose a husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace be with Burgundie,
Since that respect and Fortunes are his loue,
I ſhall not be his wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fra.
SPEECH.LINE: Fairest Cordelia, that art mo’t rich being poore,
Mo’t choise forsaken, and mo’t lou’d despis’d,
Thee and thy vertues here I ſeize vpon,
Be it lawfull I take vp what’s cast away.
Gods, Gods! ‘Tis ſtrange, that from their cold'st neglect
My Loue ſhould kindle to enflam’d respect.
Thy dowreleſſe Daughter King, throwne to my chance,
Is Queene of vs, of ours, and our faire France:
Not all the Dukes of watrish Burgundy,
Can buy this vnpriz’d precious Maid of me.
Bid them farewell Cordelia, though vnkinde,
Thou loosest here a better where to finde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast her France, let her be thine, for we
Haue no ſuch Daughter, nor ſhall euer ſee
That face of hers againe, therfore be gone,
Without our Grace, our Loue, our Benizon:
Come Noble Burgundie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fra.
SPEECH.LINE: Bid farwell to your Sisters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: The Iewels of our Father, with wash’d eies
Cordelia leaues you, I know you what you are,
And like a Sister am mo’t loth to call
Your faults as they are named. Loue well our Father:
To your profeſſed bosomes I commit him,
But yet alas, ſtood I within his Grace,
I would prefer him to a better place,
So farewell to you both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Regn.
SPEECH.LINE: Prescribe not vs our dutie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Let your ſtudy
Be to content your Lord, who hath receiu’d you
At Fortunes almes, you haue obedience ſcanted,
And well are worth the want that you haue wanted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Time ſhall vnfold what plighted cunning hides,
Who couers faults, at last with ſhame derides:
Well may you prosper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fra
SPEECH.LINE: Come my faire Cordelia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Sister, it is not little I haue to ſay,
Of what mo’t neerely appertaines to vs both,
I thinke our Father will hence to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: That's mo’t certaine, and with you: next moneth with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſee how full of changes his age is, the ob-seruation we haue made of it hath beene little; he alwaies lou’d our Sister mo’t, and with what poore iudgement he hath now cast her off, appeares too groſſely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis the infirmity of his age, yet he hath euer but ſlenderly knowne himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: The best and ſoundest of his time hath bin but rash, then must we looke from his age, to receiue not a-lone the imperfections of long ingraffed condition, but therewithall the vnruly way-wardneſſe, that infirme and cholericke yeares bring with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Such vnconstant ſtarts are we like to haue from him, as this of Kents banishment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: There is further complement of leaue-taking be-tweene France and him, pray you let vs ſit together, if our Father carry authority with ſuch disposition as he beares, this last ſurrender of his will but offend vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall further thinke of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon
SPEECH.LINE: We must do ſomething, and i'th’ heate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou Nature art my Goddeſſe, to thy Law
My ſeruices are bound, wherefore ſhould I
Stand in the plague of custome, and permit
The curiosity of Nations, to depriue me?
For that I am ſome twelue, or fourteene Moonshines
Lag of a Brother? Why Bastard? Wherefore base?
When my Dimensions are as well compact,
My minde as generous, and my ſhape as true
As honeſt Madams iſſue? Why brand they vs
With Base? With basenes Bastardie? Base, Base?
Who in the lustie ſtealth of Nature, take
More composition, and fierce qualitie,
Then doth within a dull ſtale tyred bed
Goe to th’ creating a whole tribe of Fops
Got 'tweene a ſleepe, and wake? Well then,
Legitimate Edgar, I must haue your land,
Our Fathers loue, is to the Bastard Edmond,
As to th’ legitimate: fine word: Legitimate.
Well, my Legittimate, if this Letter ſpeed,
And my inuention thriue, Edmond the base
Shall to'th’ Legitimate: I grow, I prosper:
Now Gods, ſtand vp for Bastards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Kent banish’d thus? and France in choller parted?
And the King gone to night? Prescrib’d his powre,
Confin’d to exhibition? All this done
Vpon the gad? Edmond, how now? What newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: So please your Lordship, none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſo earnestly ſeeke you to put vp y Letter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I know no newes, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: What Paper were you reading?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: No? what needed then that terrible dispatch of it into your Pocket? The quality of nothing, hath not ſuch neede to hide it ſelfe. Let's ſee: come, if it bee no-thing, I ſhall not neede Spectacles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech you Sir, pardon mee; it is a Letter from my Brother, that I haue not all ore-read; and for ſo much as I haue perus’d, I finde it not fit for your ore-loo-king. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me the Letter, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall offend, either to detaine, or giue it:
The Contents, as in part I vnderstand them,
Are too blame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's ſee, let's ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope for my Brothers iustification, hee wrote this but as an eſſay, or taste of my Vertue. Glou. reads. This policie, and reuerence of Age, makes the world bitter to the best of our times: keepes our Fortunes from vs, till our oldneſſe cannot rellish them. I begin to finde an idle and fond bondage, in the oppreſſion of aged tyranny, who ſwayes not as it hath power, but as it is ſuffer’d. Come to me, that of this I may ſpeake more. If our Father would ſleepe till I wak’d him, you ſhould enioy halfe his Reuennew for euer, and liue the beloued of your Brother. Edgar. Hum? Conspiracy? Sleepe till I wake him, you ſhould enioy halfe his Reuennew: my Sonne Edgar, had hee a hand to write this? A heart and braine to breede it in? When came you to this? Who brought it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: It was not brought mee, my Lord; there's the cunning of it. I found it throwne in at the Casement of my Cloſſet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: You know the character to be your Brothers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: If the matter were good my Lord, I durst ſwear it were his: but in respect of that, I would faine thinke it were not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: It is his.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: It is his hand, my Lord: but I hope his heart is not in the Contents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Has he neuer before ſounded you in this busines?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer my Lord. But I haue heard him oft main-taine it to be fit, that Sonnes at perfect age, and Fathers declin’d, the Father ſhould bee as Ward to the Son, and the Sonne manage his Reuennew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: O Villain, villain: his very opinion in the Let-ter. Abhorred Villaine, vnnaturall, detested, brutish Villaine; worse then brutish: Go ſirrah, ſeeke him: Ile apprehend him. Abhominable Villaine, where is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not well know my L[ord]. If it ſhall please you to ſuspend your indignation against my Brother, til you can deriue from him better testimony of his intent, you ſhold run a certaine course: where, if you violently proceed a-gainst him, mistaking his purpose, it would make a great gap in your owne Honor, and ſhake in peeces, the heart of his obedience. I dare pawne downe my life for him, that he hath writ this to feele my affection to your Honor, & to no other pretence of danger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke you ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: If your Honor iudge it meete, I will place you where you ſhall heare vs conferre of this, and by an Auri-cular aſſurance haue your ſatisfaction, and that without any further delay, then this very Euening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot bee ſuch a Monster. Edmond ſeeke him out: winde me into him, I pray you: frame the Bu-sineſſe after your owne wisedome. I would vnstate my ſelfe, to be in a due resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſeeke him Sir, presently: conuey the bu-sineſſe as I ſhall find meanes, and acquaint you withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: These late Eclipses in the Sun and Moone por-tend no good to vs: though the wisedome of Nature can reason it thus, and thus, yet Nature finds it ſelfe ſcourg’d by the ſequent effects. Loue cooles, friendship falls off, Brothers diuide. In Cities, mutinies; in Countries, dis-cord; in Pallaces, Treason; and the Bond crack’d, 'twixt Sonne and Father. This villaine of mine comes vnder the prediction; there's Son against Father, the King fals from byas of Nature, there's Father against Childe. We haue ſeene the best of our time. Machinations, hollowneſſe, treacherie, and all ruinous disorders follow vs disquietly to our Graues. Find out this Villain, Edmond, it ſhall lose thee nothing, do it carefully: and the Noble & true-har-ted Kent banish’d; his offence, honesty. ‘Tis ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the excellent foppery of the world, that when we are ſicke in fortune, often the ſurfets of our own behauiour, we make guilty of our disasters, the Sun, the Moone, and Starres, as if we were villaines on neceſſitie, Fooles by heauenly compulsion, Knaues, Theeues, and Treachers by Sphericall predominance. Drunkards, Ly-ars, and Adulterers by an inforc’d obedience of Planatary influence; and all that we are euill in, by a diuine thru-sting on. An admirable euasion of Whore-master-man, to lay his Goatish disposition on the charge of a Starre, My father compounded with my mother vnder the Dra-gons taile, and my Natiuity was vnder Vrsa Maior, ſo that it followes, I am rough and Leacherous. I ſhould haue bin that I am, had the maidenlest Starre in the Fir-mament twinkled on my bastardizing. Enter Edgar. Pat: he comes like the Catastrophe of the old Comedie: my Cue is villanous Melancholly, with a ſighe like Tom o' Bedlam. — O these Eclipses do portend these diui-sions. Fa, Sol, La, Me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Brother Edmond, what ſerious con-templation are you in?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I am thinking Brother of a prediction I read this other day, what ſhould follow these Eclipses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you busie your ſelfe with that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I promise you, the effects he writes of, ſucceede vnhappily. When ſaw you my Father last?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: The night gone by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Spake you with him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: I, two houres together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Parted you in good termes? Found you no dis-pleasure in him, by word, nor countenance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: None at all,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Bethink your ſelfe wherein you may haue offen-ded him: and at my entreaty forbeare his presence, vntill ſome little time hath qualified the heat of his displeasure, which at this instant ſo rageth in him, that with the mis-chiefe of your person, it would ſcarsely alay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Some Villaine hath done me wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edm.
SPEECH.LINE: That's my feare, I pray you haue a continent forbearance till the ſpeed of his rage goes ſlower: and as I ſay, retire with me to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to heare my Lord ſpeake: pray ye goe, there's my key: if you do ſtirre abroad, goe arm’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Arm’d, Brother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edm.
SPEECH.LINE: Brother, I aduise you to the best, I am no honeſt man, if ther be any good meaning toward you: I haue told you what I haue ſeene, and heard: But faintly. Nothing like the image, and horror of it, pray you away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I heare from you anon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edm.
SPEECH.LINE: I do ſerue you in this busineſſe:
A Credulous Father, and a Brother Noble,
Whose nature is ſo farre from doing harmes,
That he ſuspects none: on whose foolish honestie
My practises ride easie: I ſee the busineſſe.
Let me, if not by birth, haue lands by wit,
All with me's meete, that I can fashion fit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Did my Father ſtrike my Gentleman for chi-ding of his Foole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: By day and night, he wrongs me, euery howre
He flashes into one groſſe crime, or other,
That ſets vs all at ods: Ile not endure it;
His Knights grow riotous, and himselfe vpbraides vs
On euery trifle. When he returnes from hunting,
I will not ſpeake with him, ſay I am ſicke,
If you come ſlacke of former ſeruices,
You ſhall do well, the fault of it Ile anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: He's comming Madam, I heare him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Put on what weary negligence you please,
You and your Fellowes: I’de haue it come to question;
If he distaste it, let him to my Sister,
Whose mind and mine I know in that are one,
Remember what I haue ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Well Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: And let his Knights haue colder lookes among you: what growes of it no matter, aduise your fellowes ſo, Ile write ſtraight to my Sister to hold my course; pre-pare for dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: If but as will I other accents borrow,
That can my ſpeech defuse, my good intent
May carry through it ſelfe to that full iſſue
For which I raiz’d my likeneſſe. Now banisht Kent,
If thou canst ſerue where thou dost ſtand condemn’d,
So may it come, thy Master whom thou lou'st,
Shall find thee full of labours.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Hornes within. Enter Lear and Attendants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me not ſtay a iot for dinner, go get it rea-dy: how now, what art thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: A man Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What dost thou profeſſe? What would'st thou with vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I do profeſſe to be no leſſe then I ſeeme; to ſerue him truely that will put me in trust, to loue him that is honeſt, to conuerse with him that is wise and ſaies little, to feare iudgement, to fight when I cannot choose, and to eate no fish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: A very honeſt hearted Fellow, and as poore as the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou be'st as poore for a ſubiect, as hee's for a
King, thou art poore enough. What wouldst thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Seruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Who wouldst thou ſerue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: You.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Do'st thou know me fellow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: No Sir, but you haue that in your countenance, which I would faine call Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What's that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Authority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſeruices canst thou do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I can keepe honeſt counsaile, ride, run, marre a curious tale in telling it, and deliuer a plaine meſſage bluntly: that which ordinary men are fit for, I am qual-lified in, and the best of me, is Dilligence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: How old art thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo young Sir to loue a woman for ſinging, nor ſo old to dote on her for any thing. I haue yeares on my backe forty eight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Follow me, thou ſhalt ſerue me, if I like thee no worse after dinner, I will not part from thee yet. Dinner ho, dinner, where's my knaue? my Foole? Go you and call my Foole hither. You you Sirrah, where's my Daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste
SPEECH.LINE: So please you—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaies the Fellow there? Call the Clot-pole backe: wher's my Foole? Ho, I thinke the world's asleepe, how now? Where's that Mungrell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knigh.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſaies my Lord, your Daughters is not well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Why came not the ſlaue backe to me when I call’d him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knigh.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner, he would not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: He would not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knight.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I know not what the matter is, but to my iudgement your Highneſſe is not entertain’d with that Ceremonious affection as you were wont, theres a great abatement of kindneſſe appeares as well in the generall dependants, as in the Duke himselfe also, and your Daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? Saist thou ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knigh.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech you pardon me my Lord, if I bee mistaken, for my duty cannot be ſilent, when I thinke your Highneſſe wrong’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou but remembrest me of mine owne Con-ception, I haue perceiued a mo’t faint neglect of late, which I haue rather blamed as mine owne iealous curio-sitie, then as a very pretence and purpose of vnkindneſſe; I will looke further intoo't: but where's my Foole? I haue not ſeene him this two daies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knight.
SPEECH.LINE: Since my young Ladies going into France
Sir, the Foole hath much pined away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No more of that, I haue noted it well, goe you and tell my Daughter, I would ſpeake with her. Goe you call hither my Foole; Oh you Sir, you, come you hither Sir, who am I Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: My Ladies Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: My Ladies Father? my Lords knaue, you whor-son dog, you ſlaue, you curre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I am none of these my Lord,
I beseech your pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you bandy lookes with me, you Rascall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile not be ſtrucken my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor tript neither, you base Foot-ball plaier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee fellow.
Thou ſeru'st me, and Ile loue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſir, arise, away, Ile teach you differences: away, away, if you will measure your lubbers length a-gaine, tarry, but away, goe too, haue you wisedome, ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Now my friendly knaue I thanke thee, there's earnest of thy ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me hire him too, here's my Coxcombe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: How now my pretty knaue, how dost thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrah, you were best take my Coxcombe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Why my Boy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? for taking ones part that’s out of fauour, nay, & thou canst not ſmile as the wind ſits, thou'lt catch colde ſhortly, there take my Coxcombe; why this fellow ha's banish’d two on's Daughters, and did the third a bleſſing against his will, if thou follow him, thou must needs weare my Coxcombe. How now Nunckle? would I had two Coxcombes and two Daughters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Why my Boy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fool.
SPEECH.LINE: If I gaue them all my liuing, I'ld keepe my Cox-combes my ſelfe, there's mine, beg another of thy Daughters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Take heed Sirrah, the whip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Truth's a dog must to kennell, hee must bee whipt out, when the Lady Brach may ſtand by'th’ fire and ſtinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: A pestilent gall to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirha, Ile teach thee a ſpeech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke it Nuncle;
Haue more then thou ſhowest,
Speake leſſe then thou knowest,
Lend leſſe then thou owest,
Ride more then thou goest,
Learne more then thou trowest,
Set leſſe then thou throwest;
Leaue thy drinke and thy whore,
And keepe in a dore,
And thou ſhalt haue more,
Then two tens to a ſcore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: This is nothing Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ‘tis like the breath of an vnfeed Lawyer, you gaue me nothing for't, can you make no vse of no-thing Nuncle?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Why no Boy,
Nothing can be made out of nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee tell him, ſo much the rent of his land comes to, he will not beleeue a Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: A bitter Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Do'st thou know the difference my Boy, be-tweene a bitter Foole, and a ſweet one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No Lad, teach me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Nunckle, giue me an egge, and Ile giue thee two Crownes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What two Crownes ſhall they be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Why after I haue cut the egge i'th’ middle and eate vp the meate, the two Crownes of the egge: when thou clouest thy Crownes i'th’ middle, and gau'st away both parts, thou boar'st thine Aſſe on thy backe o’re the durt, thou hadst little wit in thy bald crowne, when thou gau'st thy golden one away; if I ſpeake like my ſelfe in this, let him be whipt that first findes it ſo. Fooles had nere leſſe grace in a yeere, For wisemen are growne foppish, And know not how their wits to weare, Their manners are ſo apish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Le.
SPEECH.LINE: When were you wont to be ſo full of Songs ſirrah?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue vsed it Nunckle, ere ſince thou mad'st thy Daughters thy Mothers, for when thou gau'st them the rod, and put'st downe thine owne breeches, then they For ſodaine ioy did weepe, And I for ſorrow ſung, That ſuch a King ſhould play bo-peepe, And goe the Foole among. Pry'thy Nunckle keepe a Schoolemaster that can teach thy Foole to lie, I would faine learne to lie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: And you lie ſirrah, wee'l haue you whipt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: I maruell what kin thou and thy daughters are, they'l haue me whipt for ſpeaking true: thou'lt haue me whipt for lying, and ſometimes I am whipt for holding my peace. I had rather be any kind o' thing then a foole, and yet I would not be thee Nunckle, thou hast pared thy wit o' both ſides, and left nothing i'th’ middle; heere comes one o'the parings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Daughter? what makes that Frontlet on? You are too much of late i'th’ frowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to care for her frowning, now thou art an O with-out a figure, I am better then thou art now, I am a Foole, thou art nothing. Yes forsooth I will hold my tongue, ſo your face bids me, though you ſay nothing. Mum, mum, he that keepes nor crust, nor crum, Weary of all, ſhall want ſome. That's a ſheal’d Pescod.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Not only Sir this, your all-lycenc’d Foole,
But other of your insolent retinue
Do hourely Carpe and Quarrell, breaking forth
In ranke, and (not to be endur’d) riots Sir.
I had thought by making this well knowne vnto you,
To haue found a ſafe redreſſe, but now grow fearefull
By what your ſelfe too late haue ſpoke and done,
That you protect this course, and put it on
By your allowance, which if you ſhould, the fault
Would not ſcape censure, nor the redreſſes ſleepe,
Which in the tender of a wholesome weale,
Mighty in their working do you that offence,
Which else were ſhame, that then neceſſitie
Will call discreet proceeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: For you know Nunckle, the Hedge-Sparrow fed the Cuckoo ſo long, that it's had it head bit off by it young, ſo out went the Candle, and we were left dark-ling. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you our Daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I would you would make vse of your good wisedome
(Whereof I know you are fraught), and put away
These dispositions, which of late transport you
From what you rightly are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: May not an Aſſe know, when the Cart drawes the Horse? Whoop Iugge I loue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Do's any heere know me?
This is not Lear:
Do's Lear walke thus? Speake thus? Where are his eies?
Either his Notion weakens, his Discernings
Are Lethargied. Ha! Waking? ‘Tis not ſo?
Who is it that can tell me who I am?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Lears ſhadow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Your name, faire Gentlewoman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: This admiration Sir, is much o'th’ ſauour
Of other your new prankes. I do beseech you
To vnderstand my purposes aright:
As you are Old, and Reuerend, ſhould be Wise.
Heere do you keepe a hundred Knights and Squires,
Men ſo disorder’d, ſo debosh’d and bold,
That this our Court infected with their manners,
Shewes like a riotous Inne; Epicurisme and Lust
Makes it more like a Tauerne, or a Brothell,
Then a grac’d Pallace. The ſhame it ſelfe doth ſpeake
For instant remedy. Be then desir’d
By her, that else will take the thing ſhe begges,
A little to disquantity your Traine,
And the remainders that ſhall ſtill depend,
To be ſuch men as may besort your Age,
Which know themselues, and you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Darkneſſe, and Diuels.
Saddle my horses: call my Traine together.
Degenerate Bastard, Ile not trouble thee;
Yet haue I left a daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſtrike my people, and your disorder’d rable, make Seruants of their Betters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Wœ, that too late repents:
Is it your will, ſpeake Sir? Prepare my Horses.
Ingratitude! thou Marble-hearted Fiend,
More hideous when thou ſhew'st thee in a Child,
Then the Sea-monster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray Sir be patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Detested Kite, thou lyest.
My Traine are men of choice, and rarest parts,
That all particulars of dutie know,
And in the mo’t exact regard, ſupport
The worships of their name. O mo’t ſmall fault,
How vgly did'st thou in Cordelia ſhew?
Which like an Engine, wrencht my frame of Nature
From the fixt place: drew from my heart all loue,
And added to the gall. O Lear, Lear, Lear!
Beate at this gate that let thy Folly in,
And thy deere Iudgement out. Go, go, my people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I am guiltleſſe, as I am ignorant
Of what hath moued you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: It may be ſo, my Lord.
Heare Nature, heare deere Goddeſſe, heare:
Suspend thy purpose, if thou did'st intend
To make this Creature fruitfull:
Into her Wombe conuey ſtirrility,
Drie vp in her the Organs of increase,
And from her derogate body, neuer ſpring
A Babe to honor her. If ſhe must teeme,
Create her childe of Spleene, that it may liue
And be a thwart disnatur’d torment to her.
Let it ſtampe wrinkles in her brow of youth,
With cadent Teares fret Channels in her cheekes,
Turne all her Mothers paines, and benefits
To laughter, and contempt: That ſhe may feele,
How ſharper then a Serpents tooth it is,
To haue a thankleſſe Childe. Away, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Gods that we adore,
Whereof comes this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer afflict your ſelfe to know more of it:
But let his disposition haue that ſcope
As dotage giues it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What fiftie of my Followers at a clap?
Within a fortnight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter, Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile tell thee:
Life and death, I am asham’d
That thou hast power to ſhake my manhood thus,
That these hot teares, which breake from me perforce
Should make thee worth them.
Blastes and Fogges vpon thee:
Th’ vntented woundings of a Fathers curse
Pierce euerie ſense about thee. Old fond eyes,
Beweepe this cause againe, Ile plucke ye out,
And cast you with the waters that you loose
To temper Clay. Ha? Let it be ſo.
I haue another daughter,
Who I am ſure is kinde and comfortable:
When ſhe ſhall heare this of thee, with her nailes
Shee'l flea thy Woluish visage. Thou ſhalt finde,
That Ile resume the ſhape which thou dost thinke
I haue cast off for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you marke that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot be ſo partiall Gonerill,
To the great loue I beare you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you content. What Oswald, hoa?
You Sir, more Knaue then Foole, after your Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Nunkle Lear, Nunkle Lear,
Tarry, take the Foole with thee:
A Fox, when one has caught her,
And ſuch a Daughter,
Should ſure to the Slaughter,
If my Cap would buy a Halter,
So the Foole followes after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: This man hath had good Counsell,
A hundred Knights?
‘Tis politike, and ſafe to let him keepe
At point a hundred Knights: yes, that on euerie dreame,
Each buz, each fancie, each complaint, dislike,
He may enguard his dotage with their powres,
And hold our liues in mercy. Oswald, I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, you may feare too farre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Safer then trust too farre;
Let me ſtill take away the harmes I feare,
Not feare ſtill to be taken. I know his heart,
What he hath vtter’d I haue writ my Sister:
If ſhe ſustaine him, and his hundred Knights
When I haue ſhew’d th’ vnfitneſſe.
How now Oswald?
What haue you writ that Letter to my Sister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Take you ſome company, and away to horse,
Informe her full of my particular feare,
And thereto adde ſuch reasons of your owne,
As may compact it more. Get you gone,
And hasten your returne; no, no, my Lord,
This milky gentleneſſe, and course of yours
Though I condemne not, yet vnder pardon
You are much more at task for want of wisedome,
Then prais’d for harmefull mildneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: How farre your eies may pierce I cannot tell;
Striuing to better, oft we marre what’s well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well, th’ euent.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Lear, Kent, Gentleman, and Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Go you before to Gloster with these Letters; acquaint my Daughter no further with any thing you know, then comes from her demand out of the Letter, if your Dilligence be not ſpeedy, I ſhall be there afore you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not ſleepe my Lord, till I haue deliuered your Letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: If a mans braines were in's heeles, wert not in danger of kybes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: I Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Then I prythee be merry, thy wit ſhall not go ſlip-shod.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, ha.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fool.
SPEECH.LINE: Shalt ſee thy other Daughter will vse thee kind-ly, for though ſhe's as like this, as a Crabbe's like an Apple, yet I can tell what I can tell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What can'st tell Boy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: She will taste as like this as, a Crabbe do's to a Crab: thou canst, tell why ones nose ſtands i'th’ middle on's face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Why to keepe ones eyes of either ſide 's nose, that what a man cannot ſmell out, he may ſpy into.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: I did her wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Can'st tell how an Oyster makes his ſhell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I neither; but I can tell why a Snaile ha's a house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Why to put's head in, not to giue it away to his daughters, and leaue his hornes without a case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: I will forget my Nature, ſo kind a Father? Be my Horſſes ready?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy Aſſes are gone about 'em; the reason why the ſeuen Starres are no mo then ſeuen, is a pretty reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Because they are not eight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes indeed, thou would'st make a good Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: To tak't againe perforce; Monster Ingratitude!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou wert my Foole Nunckle, Il’d haue thee beaten for being old before thy time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: How's that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhouldst not haue bin old, till thou hadst bin wise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: O let me not be mad, not mad ſweet Heauen: keepe me in temper, I would not be mad. How now are the Horses ready?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Ready my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fool.
SPEECH.LINE: She that’s a Maid now, & laughs at my departure,
Shall not be a Maid long, vnleſſe things be cut ſhorter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Saue thee Curan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: And you Sir, I haue bin
With your Father, and giuen him notice
That the Duke of Cornwall, and Regan his Ducheſſe
Will be here with him this night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: How comes that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay I know not, you haue heard of the newes a-broad, I meane the whisper’d ones, for they are yet but ear-kiſſing arguments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I: pray you what are they?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you heard of no likely Warres toward,
'Twixt the Dukes of Cornwall, and Albany?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: You may do then in time,
Fare you well Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke be here to night? The better best,
This weaues it ſelfe perforce into my busineſſe,
My Father hath ſet guard to take my Brother,
And I haue one thing of a queazie question
Which I must act, Briefeneſſe, and Fortune worke.
Brother, a word, discend; Brother I ſay,
My Father watches: O Sir, fly this place,
Intelligence is giuen where you are hid;
You haue now the good aduantage of the night,
Haue you not ſpoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornewall?
Hee's comming hither, now i'th’ night, i'th’ haste,
And Regan with him, haue you nothing ſaid
Vpon his partie 'gainst the Duke of Albany?
Aduise your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſure on't, not a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I heare my Father comming, pardon me:
In cunning, I must draw my Sword vpon you:
Draw, ſeeme to defend your ſelfe,
Now quit you well.
Yeeld, come before my Father, light hoa, here,
Fly Brother, Torches, Torches, ſo farewell.
Some blood drawne on me, would beget opinion
Of my more fierce endeauour. I haue ſeene drunkards
Do more then this in ſport; Father, Father,
Stop, ſtop, no helpe?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Gloster, and Seruants with Torches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Edmund, where's the villaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Here ſtood he in the dark, his ſharpe Sword out,
Mumbling of wicked charmes, coniuring the Moone
To ſtand auspicious Mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: But where is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke Sir, I bleed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the villaine, Edmund?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Fled this way Sir, when by no meanes he could.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Pursue him, ho: go after. By no meanes, what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Perswade me to the murther of your Lordship,
But that I told him the reuenging Gods,
'Gainst Paricides did all the thunder bend,
Spoke with how manifold, and ſtrong a Bond
The Child was bound to'th’ Father; Sir in fine,
Seeing how lothly opposite I ſtood
To his vnnaturall purpose, in fell motion
With his prepared Sword, he charges home
My vnprouided body, latch’d mine arme;
And when he ſaw my best alarum’d ſpirits
Bold in the quarrels right, rouz’d to th’ encounter,
Or whether gasted by the noyse I made,
Full ſodainely he fled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him fly farre:
Not in this Land ſhall he remaine vncaught
And found; dispatch, the Noble Duke my Master,
My worthy Arch and Patron comes to night,
By his authoritie I will proclaime it,
That he which finds him ſhall deserue our thankes,
Bringing the murderous Coward to the ſtake:
He that conceales him death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: When I diſſwaded him from his intent,
And found him pight to doe it, with curst ſpeech
I threaten’d to discouer him; he replied,
Thou vnpoſſeſſing Bastard, dost thou thinke,
If I would ſtand against thee, would the reposall
Of any trust, vertue, or worth in thee
Make thy words faith’d? No, what ſhould I denie,
(As this I would, though thou didst produce
My very Character) I'ld turne it all
To thy ſuggestion, plot, and damned practise:
And thou must make a dullard of the world,
If they not thought the profits of my death
Were very pregnant and potentiall ſpirits
To make thee ſeeke it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſtrange and fastned Villaine,
Would he deny his Letter, ſaid he?
Harke, the Dukes Trumpets, I know not wher he comes;
All Ports Ile barre, the villaine ſhall not ſcape,
The Duke must grant me that: besides, his picture
I will ſend farre and neere, that all the kingdome
May haue due note of him, and of my land,
(Loyall and naturall Boy) Ile worke the meanes
To make thee capable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: How now my Noble friend, ſince I came hither
(Which I can call but now,) I haue heard ſtrangeneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be true, all vengeance comes too ſhort
Which can pursue th’ offender; how dost my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Madam, my old heart is crack’d, it's crack’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: What, did my Fathers Godsonne ſeeke your life?
He whom my Father nam’d, your Edgar?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lady, Lady, ſhame would haue it hid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Was he not companion with the riotous Knights
That tended vpon my Father?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not Madam, ‘tis too bad, too bad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Madam, he was of that consort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: No maruaile then, though he were ill affected,
‘Tis they haue put him on the old mans death,
To haue th’ expence and wast of his Reuenues:
I haue this present euening from my Sister
Beene well inform’d of them, and with ſuch cautions,
That if they come to ſoiourne at my house,
Ile not be there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I, aſſure thee Regan;
Edmund, I heare that you haue ſhewne your Father
A Child-like Office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: It was my duty Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: He did bewray his practise, and receiu’d
This hurt you ſee, ſtriuing to apprehend him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he pursued?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: If he be taken, he ſhall neuer more
Be fear’d of doing harme, make your owne purpose,
How in my ſtrength you please: for you Edmund,
Whose vertue and obedience doth this instant
So much commend it ſelfe, you ſhall be ours,
Nature's of ſuch deepe trust, we ſhall much need:
You we first ſeize on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall ſerue you Sir truely, how euer else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: For him I thanke your Grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: You know not why we came to visit you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus out of ſeason, thredding darke ey’d night,
Occasions Noble Gloster of ſome prize,
Wherein we must haue vse of your aduise.
Our Father he hath writ, ſo hath our Sister,
Of differences, which I best thought it fit
To answere from our home: the ſeuerall Meſſengers
From hence attend dispatch, our good old Friend,
Lay comforts to your bosome, and bestow
Your needfull counsaile to our busineſſes,
Which craues the instant vse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſerue you Madam,
Your Graces are right welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Good dawning to thee Friend, art of this house?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Where may we ſet our horses?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I'th’ myre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee, if thou lou'st me, tell me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then I care not for thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: If I had thee in Lipsbury Pinfold, I would make thee care for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do'st thou vse me thus? I know thee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Fellow I know thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: What do'st thou know me for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: A Knaue, a Rascall, an eater of broken meates, a base, proud, ſhallow, beggerly, three-suited-hundred pound, filthy woosted-stocking knaue, a Lilly-liuered, action-taking, whoreson glaſſe-gazing ſuper-seruiceable finicall Rogue, one Trunke-inheriting ſlaue, one that would'st be a Baud in way of good ſeruice, and art no-thing but the composition of a Knaue, Begger, Coward, Pandar, and the Sonne and Heire of a Mungrill Bitch, one whom I will beate into clamours whining, if thou deny'st the least ſillable of thy addition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what a monstrous Fellow art thou, thus to raile on one, that is neither knowne of thee, nor knowes thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: What a brazen-fac’d Varlet art thou, to deny thou knowest me? Is it two dayes ſince I tript vp thy heeles, and beate thee before the King? Draw you rogue, for though it be night, yet the Moone ſhines, Ile make a ſop oth' Moonshine of you, you whoreson Cullyenly Barber-monger, draw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, I haue nothing to do with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Draw you Rascall, you come with Letters a-gainst the King, and take Vanitie the puppets part, a-gainst the Royaltie of her Father: draw you Rogue, or Ile ſo carbonado your ſhanks, draw you Rascall, come your waies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe, ho, murther, helpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Strike you ſlaue: ſtand rogue, ſtand you neat ſlaue, ſtrike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe hoa, murther, murther.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Bastard, Cornewall, Regan, Gloster, Seruants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, what’s the matter? Part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: With you goodman Boy, if you please, come,
Ile flesh ye, come on yong Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Weapons? Armes? what’s the matter here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Keepe peace vpon your liues, he dies that ſtrikes againe, what is the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: The Meſſengers from our Sister, and the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your difference, ſpeake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſcarce in breath my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: No Maruell, you haue ſo bestir’d your valour, you cowardly Rascall, nature disclaimes in thee: a Taylor made thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a ſtrange fellow, a Taylor make a man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: A Taylor Sir, a Stone-cutter, or a Painter, could not haue made him ſo ill, though they had bin but two yeares oth' trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake yet, how grew your quarrell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: This ancient Ruffian Sir, whose life I haue ſpar’d at ſute of his gray-beard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou whoreson Zed, thou vnneceſſary letter: my Lord, if you will giue me leaue, I will tread this vn-boulted villaine into morter, and daube the wall of a Iakes with him. Spare my gray-beard, you wagtaile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace ſirrah,
You beastly knaue, know you no reuerence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Sir, but anger hath a priuiledge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Why art thou angrie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſuch a ſlaue as this ſhould weare a Sword,
Who weares no honesty: ſuch ſmiling rogues as these,
Like Rats oft bite the holy cords a twaine,
Which are t’ intrince, t’ vnloose: ſmooth euery paſſion
That in the natures of their Lords rebell,
Being oile to fire, ſnow to the colder moodes,
Reuenge, affirme, and turne their Halcion beakes
With euery gall, and varry of their Masters,
Knowing naught (like dogges) but following:
A plague vpon your Epilepticke visage,
Smoile you my ſpeeches, as I were a Foole?
Goose, if I had you vpon Sarum Plaine,
I'ld driue ye cackling home to Camelot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou mad old Fellow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glost.
SPEECH.LINE: How fell you out, ſay that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: No contraries hold more antipathy,
Then I, and ſuch a knaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do'st thou call him Knaue?
What is his fault?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: His countenance likes me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: No more perchance do's mine, nor his, nor hers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ‘tis my occupation to be plaine,
I haue ſeene better faces in my Time,
Then ſtands on any ſhoulder that I ſee
Before me, at this instant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: This is ſome Fellow,
Who hauing beene prais’d for bluntneſſe, doth affect
A ſaucy roughnes, and constraines the garb
Quite from his Nature. He cannot flatter he,
An honeſt mind and plaine, he must ſpeake truth,
And they will take it ſo, if not, hee's plaine.
These kind of Knaues I know, which in this plainneſſe
Harbour more craft, and more corrupter ends,
Then twenty ſilly-ducking obseruants,
That ſtretch their duties nicely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, in good faith, in ſincere verity,
Vnder th’ allowance of your great aspect,
Whose influence like the wreath of radient fire
On flickring Phœbus front.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: What mean'st by this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: To go out of my dialect, which you discom-mend ſo much; I know Sir, I am no flatterer, he that be-guild you in a plaine accent, was a plaine Knaue, which for my part I will not be, though I ſhould win your displeasure to entreat me too't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: What was th’ offence you gaue him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer gaue him any:
It pleas’d the King his Master very late
To ſtrike at me vpon his misconstruction,
When he compact, and flattering his displeasure
Tript me behind: being downe, insulted, rail’d,
And put vpon him ſuch a deale of Man,
That worthied him, got praises of the King,
For him attempting, who was ſelfe-subdued,
And in the fleshment of this dead exploit,
Drew on me here againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: None of these Rogues, and Cowards
But Aiax is there Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Fetch forth the Stocks?
You ſtubborne ancient Knaue, you reuerent Bragart,
Wee'l teach you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I am too old to learne:
Call not your Stocks for me, I ſerue the King.
On whose imployment I was ſent to you,
You ſhall doe ſmall respects, ſhow too bold malice
Against the Grace, and Person of my Master,
Stocking his Meſſenger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Fetch forth the Stocks;
As I haue life and Honour, there ſhall he ſit till Noone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Till noone? till night my Lord, and all night too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Madam, if I were your Fathers dog,
You ſhould not vse me ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, being his Knaue, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: This is a Fellow of the ſelfe ſame colour,
Our Sister ſpeakes of. Come, bring away the Stocks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me beseech your Grace, not to do ſo,
The King his Master, needs must take it ill
That he ſo ſlightly valued in his Meſſenger,
Should haue him thus restrained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile answere that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: My Sister may recieue it much more worſſe,
To haue her Gentleman abus’d, aſſaulted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn
SPEECH.LINE: Come my Lord, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorry for thee friend, ‘tis the Dukes pleasure,
Whose disposition all the world well knowes
Will not be rub’d nor ſtopt, Ile entreat for thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray do not Sir, I haue watch’d and trauail’d hard,
Some time I ſhall ſleepe out, the rest Ile whistle:
A good mans fortune may grow out at heeles:
Giue you good morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke's too blame in this,
'Twill be ill taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Good King, that must approue the common ſaw,
Thou out of Heauens benediction com'st
To the warme Sun.
Approach thou Beacon to this vnder Globe,
That by thy comfortable Beames I may
Peruse this Letter. Nothing almost ſees miracles
But miserie. I know ‘tis from Cordelia,
Who hath mo’t fortunately beene inform’d
Of my obscured course. And ſhall finde time
From this enormous State, ſeeking to giue
Loſſes their remedies. All weary and o’re-watch’d,
Take vantage heauie eyes, not to behold
This ſhamefull lodging. Fortune goodnight,
Smile once more, turne thy wheele.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: I heard my ſelfe proclaim’d,
And by the happy hollow of a Tree,
Escap’d the hunt. No Port is free, no place
That guard, and mo’t vnusall vigilance
Do's not attend my taking. Whiles I may ſcape
I will preserue myselfe: and am bethought
To take the basest, and mo’t poorest ſhape
That euer penury in contempt of man,
Brought neere to beast; my face Ile grime with filth,
Blanket my loines, else all my haires in knots,
And with presented nakedneſſe out-face
The Windes, and persecutions of the ſkie;
The Country giues me proofe, and president
Of Bedlam beggers, who with roaring voices,
Strike in their num’d and mortified Armes.
Pins, Wodden-prickes, Nayles, Sprigs of Rosemarie:
And with this horrible obiect, from low Farmes,
Poore pelting Villages, Sheeps-Coates, and Milles,
Sometimes with Lunaticke bans, ſometime with Praiers
Inforce their charitie: poore Turlygod poore Tom,
That's ſomething yet: Edgar I nothing am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lea.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ſtrange that they ſhould ſo depart from home,
And not ſend backe my Meſſengers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: As I learn’d,
The night before, there was no purpose in them
Of this remoue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Haile to thee Noble Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? Mak'st thou this ſhame thy pastime?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: No my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Hah, ha, he weares Cruell Garters Horses are tide by the heads, Dogges and Beares by'th’ necke, Monkies by'th’ loynes, and Men by'th’ legs: when a man ouerlustie at legs, then he weares wodden nether-stocks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What's he,
That hath ſo much thy place mistooke
To ſet thee heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: It is both he and ſhe,
Your Son, and Daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay yea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: By Iupiter I ſweare no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: By Iuno, I ſweare I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: They durst not do't:
They could not, would not do't: ‘tis worse then murther,
To do vpon respect ſuch violent outrage:
Resolue me with all modest haste, which way
Thou might'st deserue, or they impose this vsage,
Comming from vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, when at their home
I did commend your Highneſſe Letters to them,
Ere I was risen from the place, that ſhewed
My dutie kneeling, came there a reeking Poste,
Stew’d in his haste, halfe breathleſſe, painting forth
From Gonerill his Mistris, ſalutations;
Deliuer’d Letters ſpight of intermiſſion,
Which presently they read; on those contents
They ſummon’d vp their meiney, ſtraight tooke Horse,
Commanded me to follow, and attend
The leisure of their anſwer, gaue me cold lookes,
And meeting heere the other Meſſenger,
Whose welcome I perceiu’d had poison’d mine,
Being the very fellow which of late
Displaid ſo ſawcily against your Highneſſe,
Hauing more man then wit about me, drew;
He rais’d the house, with loud and coward cries,
Your Sonne and Daughter found this trespaſſe worth
The ſhame which heere it ſuffers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Winters not gon yet, if the wil’d Geese fly that way,
Fathers that weare rags, do make their Children blind,
But Fathers that beare bags, ſhall ſee their children kind.
Fortune that arrant whore, nere turns the key toth' poore.
But for all this thou ſhalt haue as many Dolors for thy
Daughters, as thou canst tell in a yeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh how this Mother ſwels vp toward my heart!
Historica paſſio, downe thou climing ſorrow,
Thy Elements below where is this Daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: With the Earle Sir, here within.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear
SPEECH.LINE: Follow me not, ſtay here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: Made you no more offence,
But what you ſpeake of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: None:
How chance the King comes with ſo ſmall a number?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: And thou hadst beene ſet i'th’ Stockes for that question, thoud'st well deseru’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Foole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l ſet thee to ſchoole to an Ant, to teach thee ther's no labouring i'th’ winter. All that follow their noses, are led by their eyes, but blinde men, and there's not a nose among twenty, but can ſmell him that’s ſtink-ing; let go thy hold when a great wheele runs downe a hill, least it breake thy necke with following. But the great one that goes vpward, let him draw thee after: when a wiseman giues thee better counsell giue me mine againe, I would haue none but knaues follow it, ſince a Foole giues it. That Sir, which ſerues and ſeekes for gaine, And followes but for forme; Will packe, when it begins to raine, And leaue thee in the ſtorme, But I will tarry, the Foole will ſtay, And let the wiseman flie: The knaue turnes Foole that runnes away, The Foole no knaue perdie. Enter Lear, and Gloster :

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Where learn’d you this Foole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Not i'th’ Stocks Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Deny to ſpeake with me?
They are ſicke, they are weary,
They haue trauail’d all the night? meere fetches,
The images of reuolt and flying off.
Fetch me a better anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: My deere Lord,
You know the fiery quality of the Duke,
How vnremoueable and fixt he is
In his owne course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Vengeance, Plague, Death, Confusion:
Fiery? What quality? Why Gloster, Gloster,
I'ld ſpeake with the Duke of Cornewall, and his wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Well my good Lord, I haue inform’d them ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Inform’d them? Do'st thou vnderstand me man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: The King would ſpeake with Cornwall,
The deere Father
Would with his Daughter ſpeake, commands, tends, ſeruice,
Are they inform’d of this? My breath and blood:
Fiery? The fiery Duke, tell the hot Duke that—
No, but not yet, may be he is not well,
Infirmity doth ſtill neglect all office,
Whereto our health is bound, we are not our ſelues,
When Nature being opprest, commands the mind
To ſuffer with the body; Ile forbeare,
And am fallen out with my more headier will,
To take the indispos’d and ſickly fit,
For the ſound man. Death on my ſtate: wherefore
Should he ſit heere? This act perswades me,
That this remotion of the Duke and her
Is practise only. Giue me my Seruant forth;
Goe tell the Duke, and's wife, Il’d ſpeake with them:
Now, presently: bid them come forth and heare me,
Or at their Chamber doore Ile beate the Drum,
Till it crie ſleepe to death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo
SPEECH.LINE: I would haue all well betwixt you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh me my heart! My rising heart! But downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Cry to it Nunckle, as the Cockney did to the Eeles, when ſhe put 'em i'th’ Paste aliue, ſhe knapt 'em o'th’ coxcombs with a ſticke, and cryed downe wantons, downe; 'twas her Brother, that in pure kindneſſe to his Horse buttered his Hay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow to you both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn
SPEECH.LINE: Haile to your Grace. Kent here ſet at liberty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to ſee your Highneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Regan, I thinke you are. I know what reason
I haue to thinke ſo, if thou ſhould'st not be glad,
I would diuorce me from thy Mother Tombe,
Sepulchring an Adultreſſe. O are you free?
Some other time for that. Beloued Regan,
Thy Sisters naught: oh Regan, ſhe hath tied
Sharpe-tooth’d vnkindneſſe, like a vulture heere,
I can ſcarce ſpeake to thee, thou'lt not beleeue
With how deprau’d a quality. Oh Regan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you Sir, take patience, I haue hope
You leſſe know how to value her desert,
Then ſhe to ſcant her dutie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Say? How is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot thinke my Sister in the least
Would faile her Obligation. If Sir perchance
She haue restrained the Riots of your Followres,
‘Tis on ſuch ground, and to ſuch wholesome end,
As cleeres her from all blame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: My curses on her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: O Sir, you are old,
Nature in you ſtands on the very Verge
Of his confine: you ſhould be rul’d, and led
By ſome discretion, that discernes your ſtate
Better then you your ſelfe: therefore I pray you,
That to our Sister, you do make returne,
Say you haue wrong’d her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Aske her forgiueneſſe?
Do you but marke how this becomes the house?
Deere daughter, I confeſſe that I am old;
Age is vnneceſſary: on my knees I begge,
That you'l vouchsafe me Rayment, Bed, and Food.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Sir, no more: these are vnsightly trickes:
Returne you to my Sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer Regan:
She hath abated me of halfe my Traine;
Look’d blacke vpon me, ſtrooke me with her Tongue
Mo’t Serpent-like, vpon the very Heart.
All the ſtor’d Vengeances of Heauen, fall
On her ingratefull top: ſtrike her yong bones
You taking Ayres, with Lameneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Fye ſir, fie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Le.
SPEECH.LINE: You nimble Lightnings, dart your blinding flames
Into her ſcornfull eyes: Infect her Beauty,
You Fen-suck’d Fogges, drawne by the powrfull Sunne,
To fall, and blister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: O the blest Gods!
So will you wish on me, when the rash moode is on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No Regan, thou ſhalt neuer haue my curse:
Thy tender-hefted Nature ſhall not giue
Thee o’re to harshneſſe: Her eyes are fierce, but thine
Do comfort, and not burne. ‘Tis not in thee
To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my Traine,
To bandy hasty words, to ſcant my ſizes,
And in conclusion, to oppose the bolt
Against my comming in. Thou better know'st
The Offices of Nature, bond of Childhood,
Effects of Curtesie, dues of Gratitude:
Thy halfe o'th’ Kingdome hast thou not forgot,
Wherein I thee endow’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg
SPEECH.LINE: Good Sir, to'th’ purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Who put my man i'th’ Stockes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: What Trumpet's that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I know't, my Sisters: this approues her Letter,
That ſhe would ſoone be heere. Is your Lady come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: This is a Slaue, whose easie borrowed pride
Dwels in the ſickly grace of her he followes.
Out Varlet, from my ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanes your Grace?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Who ſtockt my Seruant? Regan, I haue good hope
Thou did'st not know on't.
Who comes here? O Heauens!
If you do loue old men; if your ſweet ſway
Allow Obedience; if you your ſelues are old,
Make it your cause: Send downe, and take my part.
Art not asham’d to looke vpon this Beard?
O Regan, will you take her by the hand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Why not by'th’ hand Sir? How haue I offended?
All's not offence that indiscretion findes,
And dotage termes ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſides, you are too tough!
Will you yet hold?
How came my man i'th’ Stockes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſet him there, Sir: but his owne Disorders
Deseru’d much leſſe aduancement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: You? Did you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you Father being weake, ſeeme ſo.
If till the expiration of your Moneth
You will returne and ſoiourne with my Sister,
Dismiſſing halfe your traine, come then to me,
I am now from home, and out of that prouision
Which ſhall be needfull for your entertainement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Returne to her? and fifty men dismiſſ’d?
No, rather I abiure all roofes, and chuse
To wage against the enmity oth' ayre,
To be a Comrade with the Wolfe, and Owle,
Neceſſities ſharpe pinch. Returne with her?
Why the hot-bloodied France, that dowerleſſe tooke
Our yongest borne, I could as well be brought
To knee his Throne, and Squire-like pension beg,
To keepe base life a foote; returne with her?
Perswade me rather to be ſlaue and ſumpter
To this detested groome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: At your choice Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: I prythee Daughter do not make me mad,
I will not trouble thee my Child; farewell:
Wee'l no more meete, no more ſee one another.
But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my Daughter,
Or rather a disease that’s in my flesh,
Which I must needs call mine. Thou art a Byle,
A plague ſore, or imboſſed Carbuncle
In my corrupted blood. But Ile not chide thee,
Let ſhame come when it will, I do not call it,
I do not bid the Thunder-bearer ſhoote,
Nor tell tales of thee to high-iudging Ioue,
Mend when thou can'st, be better at thy leisure,
I can be patient, I can ſtay with Regan,
I and my hundred Knights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Not altogether ſo,
I look’d not for you yet, nor am prouided
For your fit welcome, giue eare Sir to my Sister,
For those that mingle reason with your paſſion,
Must be content to thinke you old, and ſo,
But ſhe knowes what ſhe doe's.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this well ſpoken?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I dare auouch it Sir, what fifty Followers?
Is it not well? What ſhould you need of more?
Yea, or ſo many? Sith that both charge and danger,
Speake 'gainst ſo great a number? How in one house
Should many people, vnder two commands
Hold amity? ‘Tis hard, almost impoſſible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Why might not you my Lord, receiue attendance
From those that ſhe cals Seruants, or from mine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Why not my Lord?
If then they chanc’d to ſlacke ye,
We could comptroll them; if you will come to me,
(For now I ſpie a danger) I entreate you
To bring but fiue and twentie, to no more
Will I giue place or notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: I gaue you all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: And in good time you gaue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Made you my Guardians, my Depositaries,
But kept a reseruation to be followed
With ſuch a number? What, must I come to you
With fiue and twenty? Regan, ſaid you ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſpeak't againe my Lord, no more with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lea.
SPEECH.LINE: Those wicked Creatures yet do look wel fauor’d
When others are more wicked, not being the worst
Stands in ſome ranke of praise, Ile go with thee,
Thy fifty yet doth double fiue and twenty,
And thou art twice her Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me my Lord;
What need you fiue and twenty? Ten? Or fiue?
To follow in a house, where twice ſo many
Haue a command to tend you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: What need one?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: O reason not the need: our basest Beggers
Are in the poorest thing ſuperfluous.
Allow not Nature, more then Nature needs:
Mans life is cheape as Beastes. Thou art a Lady;
If onely to go warme were gorgeous,
Why Nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear'st,
Which ſcarcely keepes thee warme, but for true need:
You Heauens, giue me that patience, patience I need,
You ſee me heere (you Gods) a poore old man,
As full of griefe as age, wretched in both,
If it be you that ſtirres these Daughters hearts
Against their Father, foole me not ſo much,
To beare it tamely: touch me with Noble anger,
And let not womens weapons, water drops,
Staine my mans cheekes. No you vnnaturall Hags,
I will haue ſuch reuenges on you both,
That all the world ſhall— I will do ſuch things,
What they are yet, I know not, but they ſhalbe
The terrors of the earth? you thinke Ile weepe,
No, Ile not weepe, I haue full cause of weeping.
But this heart ſhal break into a hundred thousand flawes
Or ere Ile weepe; O Foole, I ſhall go mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs withdraw, 'twill be a Storme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: This house is little, the old man and's people,
Cannot be well bestow’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis his owne blame hath put himselfe from rest,
And must needs taste his folly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: For his particular, Ile receiue him gladly,
But not one follower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: So am I purpos’d,
Where is my Lord of Gloster?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Followed the old man forth, he is return’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: The King is in high rage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Whether is he going?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: He cals to Horse, but will I know not whether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis best to giue him way, he leads himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, entreate him by no meanes to ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke the night comes on, and the high windes
Do ſorely ruffle, for many Miles about
There's ſcarce a Bush.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: O Sir, to wilfull men,
The iniuries that they themselues procure,
Must be their Schoole-Masters: ſhut vp your doores,
He is attended with a desperate traine,
And what they may incense him too, being apt,
To haue his eare abus’d, wisedome bids feare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Shut vp your doores my Lord, ‘tis a wil’d night,
