My Regan counsels well: come out oth' ſtorme.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Storme ſtill. Enter Kent, and a Gentleman, ſeuerally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's there besides foule weather?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: One minded like the weather, mo’t vnquietly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you: Where's the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Contending with the fretfull Elements;
Bids the winde blow the Earth into the Sea,
Or ſwell the curled Waters 'boue the Maine,
That things might change, or cease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: But who is with him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: None but the Foole, who labours to out-iest
His heart-strooke iniuries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I do know you,
And dare vpon the warrant of my note
Commend a deere thing to you. There is diuision
(Although as yet the face of it is couer’d
With mutuall cunning) 'twixt Albany, and Cornwall:
Who haue, as who haue not, that their great Starres
Thron’d and ſet high; Seruants, who ſeeme no leſſe,
Which are to France the Spies and Speculations
Intelligent of our State. What hath bin ſeene,
Either in ſnuffes, and packings of the Dukes,
Or the hard Reine which both of them hath borne
Against the old kinde King; or ſomething deeper,
Whereof (perchance) these are but furnishings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: I will talke further with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: No, do not:
For confirmation that I am much more
Then my out-wall; open this Purse, and take
What it containes. If you ſhall ſee Cordelia,
(As feare not but you ſhall) ſhew her this Ring,
And ſhe will tell you who that Fellow is
That yet you do not know. Fye on this Storme,
I will go ſeeke the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me your hand,
Haue you no more to ſay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Few words, but to effect more then all yet;
That when we haue found the King, in which your pain
That way, Ile this: He that first lights on him,
Holla the other.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Storme ſtill. Enter Lear, and Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Blow windes, & crack your cheeks; Rage, blow
You Cataracts, and Hyrricano's ſpout,
Till you haue drench’d our Steeples, drown the Cockes.
You Sulph'rous and Thought-executing Fires,
Vaunt-curriors of Oake-cleauing Thunder-bolts,
Sindge my white head. And thou all-shaking Thunder,
Strike flat the thicke Rotundity o'th’ world,
Cracke Natures moulds, all germaines ſpill at once
That makes ingratefull Man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: O Nunkle, Court holy-water in a dry house, is better then this Rain-water out o' doore. Good Nunkle, in, aske thy Daughters bleſſing, heere's a night pitties neither Wisemen, nor Fooles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Rumble thy belly full: ſpit Fire, ſpowt Raine:
Nor Raine, Winde, Thunder, Fire are my Daughters;
I taxe not you, you Elements with vnkindneſſe.
I neuer gaue you Kingdome, call’d you Children;
You owe me no ſubscription. Then let fall
Your horrible pleasure. Heere I ſtand your Slaue,
A poore, infirme, weake, and dispis’d old man:
But yet I call you Seruile Ministers,
That will with two pernicious Daughters ioyne
Your high-engender’d Battailes, 'gainst a head
So old, and white as this. O, ho! ‘tis foule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: He that has a house to put's head in, has a good Head-peece: The Codpiece that will house, before the head has any; The Head, and he ſhall Lowse: ſo Beggers marry many. The man y makes his Tœ, what he his Hart ſhold make, Shall of a Corne cry wœ, and turne his ſleepe to wake. For there was neuer yet faire woman, but ſhee made mouthes in a glaſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I will be the patterne of all patience,
I will ſay nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry here's Grace, and a Codpiece, that’s a
Wiseman, and a Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas Sir are you here? Things that loue night,
Loue not ſuch nights as these: The wrathfull Skies
Gallow the very wanderers of the darke
And make them keepe their Caues: Since I was man,
Such ſheets of Fire, ſuch bursts of horrid Thunder,
Such groanes of roaring Winde, and Raine, I neuer
Remember to haue heard. Mans Nature cannot carry
Th’ affliction, nor the feare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Let the great Goddes
That keepe this dreadfull pudder o’re our heads,
Finde out their enemies now. Tremble thou Wretch,
That hast within thee vndivulged Crimes
Vnwhipt of Iustice. Hide thee, thou Bloudy hand;
Thou Periur’d, and thou Simular of Vertue
That art Incestuous. Caytiffe, to peeces ſhake
That vnder couert, and conuenient ſeeming
Ha's practis’d on mans life. Close pent-vp guilts,
Riue your concealing Continents, and cry
These dreadfull Summoners grace. I am a man,
More ſinn’d against, then ſinning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, bare-headed?
Gracious my Lord, hard by heere is a Houell,
Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the Tempest:
Repose you there, while I to this hard house,
(More harder then the ſtones whereof ‘tis rais’d,
Which euen but now, demanding after you,
Deny’d me to come in) returne, and force
Their ſcanted curtesie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: My wits begin to turne.
Come on my boy. How dost my boy? Art cold?
I am cold my ſelfe. Where is this ſtraw, my Fellow?
The Art of our Neceſſities is ſtrange,
And can make vilde things precious. Come, your Houel;
Poore Foole, and Knaue, I haue one part in my heart
That's ſorry yet for thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: He that has and a little-tyne wit,
With heigh-ho, the Winde and the Raine,
Must make content with his Fortunes fit,
Though the Raine it raineth euery day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Le
SPEECH.LINE: True Boy: Come bring vs to this Houell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: This is a braue night to coole a Curtizan:
Ile ſpeake a Prophesie ere I go:
When Priests are more in word, then matter;
When Brewers marre their Malt with water;
When Nobles are their Taylors Tutors,
No Heretiques burn’d, but wenches Sutors;
When euery Case in Law, is right;
No Squire in debt, nor no poore Knight;
When Slanders do not liue in Tongues;
Nor Cut-purses come not to throngs;
When Vsurers tell their Gold i'th’ Field,
And Baudes, and whores, do Churches build,
Then ſhal the Realme of Albion, come to great confusion:
Then comes the time, who liues to ſee't,
That going ſhalbe vs’d with feet.
This prophecie Merlin ſhall make, for I liue before his time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, alacke Edmund, I like not this vnnaturall dealing; when I desired their leaue that I might pity him, they tooke from me the vse of mine owne house, charg’d me on paine of perpetuall displeasure, neither to ſpeake of him, entreat for him, or any way ſustaine him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t ſauage and vnnaturall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too; ſay you nothing. There is diuision be-tweene the Dukes, and a worſſe matter then that: I haue receiued a Letter this night, ‘tis dangerous to be ſpoken, I haue lock’d the Letter in my Cloſſet, these iniuries the King now beares, will be reuenged home; ther is part of a Power already footed, we must incline to the King, I will looke him, and priuily relieue him; goe you and maintaine talke with the Duke, that my charity be not of him perceiued; If he aske for me, I am ill, and gone to bed, if I die for it, (as no leſſe is threatned me) the King my old Master must be relieued. There is ſtrange things toward Edmund, pray you be carefull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: This Curtesie forbid thee, ſhall the Duke
Instantly know, and of that Letter too;
This ſeemes a faire deseruing, and must draw me
That which my Father looses: no leſſe then all,
The yonger rises, when the old doth fall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is the place my Lord, good my Lord enter,
The tirrany of the open night's too rough
For Nature to endure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord enter heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt breake my heart?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather breake mine owne,
Good my Lord enter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou think'st ‘tis much that this contentious ſtorme
Inuades vs to the ſkin ſo: ‘tis to thee,
But where the greater malady is fixt,
The leſſer is ſcarce felt. Thou’dst ſhun a Beare,
But if thy flight lay toward the roaring ſea,
Thou’dst meete the Beare i'th’ mouth, when the mind's free,
The bodies delicate: the tempest in my mind,
Doth from my ſences take all feeling else,
Saue what beates there, Filliall ingratitude,
Is it not as this mouth ſhould teare this hand
For lifting food too't? But I will punish home;
No, I will weepe no more; in ſuch a night,
To ſhut me out? Poure on, I will endure:
In ſuch a night as this? O Regan, Gonerill,
Your old kind Father, whose franke heart gaue all,
O that way madneſſe lies, let me ſhun that:
No more of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord enter here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee go in thy ſelfe, ſeeke thine owne ease,
This tempest will not giue me leaue to ponder
On things would hurt me more, but Ile goe in,
In Boy, go first. You houseleſſe pouertie,
Nay get thee in; Ile pray, and then Ile ſleepe.
Poore naked wretches, where ſo ere you are
That bide the pelting of this pittileſſe ſtorme,
How ſhall your House-leſſe heads, and vnfed ſides,
Your lop’d, and window’d raggedneſſe defend you
From ſeasons ſuch as these? O I haue tane
Too little care of this: Take Physicke, Pompe,
Expose thy ſelfe to feele what wretches feele,
That thou maist ſhake the ſuperflux to them,
And ſhew the Heauens more iust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Fathom, and halfe, Fathom and halfe; poore Tom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Come not in heere Nuncle, here's a ſpirit, helpe me, helpe me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue my thy hand, who's there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſpirite, a ſpirite, he ſayes his name's poore
Tom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou that dost grumble there i'th’ ſtraw? Come forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, the foule Fiend followes me, through the ſharpe Hauthorne blow the windes. Humh, goe to thy bed and warme thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Did'st thou giue all to thy Daughters? And art thou come to this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edgar.
SPEECH.LINE: Who giues any thing to poore Tom? Whom the foule fiend hath led through Fire, and through Flame, through Sword, and Whirle-Poole, o’re Bog, and Quag-mire, that hath laid Kniues vnder his Pillow, and Halters in his Pue, ſet Rats-bane by his Porredge, made him Proud of heart, to ride on a Bay trotting Horse, ouer foure incht Bridges, to course his owne ſhadow for a Traitor. Bliſſe thy fiue Wits, Toms a cold. O do, de, do, de, do, de, bliſſe thee from Whirle-Windes, Starre-blasting, and ta-king, do poore Tom ſome charitie, whom the foule Fiend vexes. There could I haue him now, and there, and there againe, and there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha's his Daughters brought him to this paſſe?
Could'st thou ſaue nothing? Would'st thou giue 'em all?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, he reseru’d a Blanket, else we had bin all ſham’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lea.
SPEECH.LINE: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous ayre
Hang fated o’re mens faults, light on thy Daughters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath no Daughters Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Death Traitor, nothing could haue ſubdu’d Nature
To ſuch a lowneſſe, but his vnkind Daughters.
Is it the fashion, that discarded Fathers,
Should haue thus little mercy on their flesh:
Iudicious punishment, 'twas this flesh begot
Those Pelicane Daughters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Pillicock ſat on Pillicock hill, alow: alow, loo, loo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: This cold night will turne vs all to Fooles, and
Madmen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edgar.
SPEECH.LINE: Take heed o'th’ foule Fiend, obey thy Pa-rents, keepe thy words Iustice, ſweare not, commit not, with mans ſworne Spouse: ſet not thy Sweet-heart on proud array. Tom's a cold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What hast thou bin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: A Seruingman? Proud in heart, and minde; that curl’d my haire, wore Gloues in my cap; ſeru’d the Lust of my Mistris heart, and did the acte of darkeneſſe with her. Swore as many Oathes, as I ſpake words, & broke them in the ſweet face of Heauen. One, that ſlept in the contriuing of Lust, and wak’d to doe it. Wine lou’d I deerely, Dice deerely; and in Woman, out-Paramour’d the Turke. False of heart, light of eare, bloody of hand; Hog in ſloth, Foxe in ſtealth, Wolfe in greedineſſe, Dog in madnes, Lyon in prey. Let not the creaking of ſhoœs, Nor the rustling of Silkes, betray thy poore heart to wo-man. Keepe thy foote out of Brothels, thy hand out of Plackets, thy pen from Lenders Bookes, and defye the foule Fiend. Still through the Hauthorne blowes the cold winde: Sayes ſuum, mun, nonny, Dolphin my Boy, Boy Sesey: let him trot by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wert better in a Graue, then to answere with thy vncouer’d body, this extremitie of the Skies. Is man no more then this? Consider him well. Thou ow'st the Worme no Silke; the Beast, no Hide; the Sheepe, no Wooll; the Cat, no perfume. Ha? Here's three on's are ſophisticated. Thou art the thing it ſelfe; vnaccommo-dated man, is no more but ſuch a poore, bare, forked A-nimall as thou art. Off, off you Lendings: Come, vn-button heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee Nunckle be contented, ‘tis a naughtie night to ſwimme in. Now a little fire in a wilde Field, were like an old Letchers heart, a ſmall ſpark, all the rest on's body, cold: Looke, heere comes a walking fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the foule Flibbertigibbet; hee begins at Curfew, and walkes at first Cocke: Hee giues the Web and the Pin, ſquints the eye, and makes the Hare-lippe; Mildewes the white Wheate, and hurts the poore Crea-ture of earth. Swithold footed thrice the old, He met the Night-Mare, and her nine-fold; Bid her a-light, and her troth-plight, And aroynt thee Witch, aroynt thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: How fares your Grace?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What's he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's there? What is't you ſeeke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: What are you there? Your Names?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Poore Tom, that eates the ſwimming Frog, the Toad, the Tod-pole, the wall-Neut, and the water: that in the furie of his heart, when the foule Fiend rages, eats Cow-dung for Sallets; ſwallowes the old Rat, and the ditch-Dogge; drinkes the green Mantle of the ſtanding Poole: who is whipt from Tything to Tything, and ſtockt, punish’d, and imprison’d: who hath three Suites to his backe, ſixe ſhirts to his body: Horse to ride, and weapon to weare: But Mice, and Rats, and ſuch ſmall Deare, Haue bin Toms food, for ſeuen long yeare: Beware my Follower. Peace Smulkin, peace thou Fiend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: What, hath your Grace no better company?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: The Prince of Darkeneſſe is a Gentleman. Modo he's call’d, and Mahu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Our flesh and blood, my Lord, is growne ſo vilde, that it doth hate what gets it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Poore Tom's a cold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Go in with me; my duty cannot ſuffer
T' obey in all your daughters hard commands:
Though their Iniunction be to barre my doores,
And let this Tyrannous night take hold vpon you,
Yet haue I ventured to come ſeeke you out,
And bring you where both fire, and food is ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: First let me talke with this Philosopher,
What is the cause of Thunder?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord take his offer,
Go into th’ house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile talke a word with this ſame lerned Theban:
What is your ſtudy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: How to preuent the Fiend, and to kill Vermine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me aske you one word in priuate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Importune him once more to go my Lord,
His wits begin t’ vnsettle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou
SPEECH.LINE: Canst thou blame him? Storm ſtill
His Daughters ſeeke his death: Ah, that good Kent,
He ſaid it would be thus: poore banish’d man:
Thou ſayest the King growes mad, Ile tell thee Friend
I am almost mad my ſelfe. I had a Sonne,
Now out-law’d from my blood: he ſought my life
But lately: very late: I lou’d him (Friend)
No Father his Sonne deerer: true to tell thee,
The greefe hath craz’d my wits. What a night's this?
I do beseech your grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: O cry you mercy, Sir:
Noble Philosopher, your company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Tom's a cold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: In fellow there, into th’ Houel; keep thee warm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let's in all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: This way, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: With him;
I will keepe ſtill with my Philosopher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord, ſooth him:
Let him take the Fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Take him you on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra, come on: go along with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, good Athenian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: No words, no words, hush.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Childe Rowland to the darke Tower came,
His word was ſtill, fie, foh, and fumme,
I ſmell the blood of a Brittish man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: I will haue my reuenge, ere I depart his house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: How my Lord, I may be censured, that Nature thus giues way to Loyaltie, ſomething feares mee to thinke of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cornw.
SPEECH.LINE: I now perceiue, it was not altogether your Brothers euill disposition made him ſeeke his death: but a prouoking merit ſet a-worke by a reprouable badneſſe in himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: How malicious is my fortune, that I must re-pent to be iust? This is the Letter which hee ſpoake of; which approues him an intelligent partie to the aduanta-ges of France. O Heauens! that this Treason were not; or not I the detector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Go with me to the Dutcheſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: If the matter of this Paper be certain, you haue mighty busineſſe in hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: True or false, it hath made thee Earle of Glou-cester: ſeeke out where thy Father is, that hee may bee ready for our apprehension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: If I finde him comforting the King, it will ſtuffe his ſuspition more fully. I will perseuer in my course of Loyalty, though the conflict be ſore betweene that, and my blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: I will lay trust vpon thee: and thou ſhalt finde a deere Father in my loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is better then the open ayre, take it thank-fully: I will peece out the comfort with what addition I can: I will not be long from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: All the powre of his wits, haue giuen way to his impatience: the Gods reward your kindneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Fraterretto cals me, and tells me Nero is an Ang-ler in the Lake of Darkneſſe: pray Innocent, and beware the foule Fiend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee Nunkle tell me, whether a madman be a Gentleman, or a Yeoman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: A King, a King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: No, he's a Yeoman, that ha's a Gentleman to his Sonne: for hee's a mad Yeoman that ſees his Sonne a Gentleman before him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: To haue a thousand with red burning ſpits
Come hizzing in vpon 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſe thy fiue wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: O pitty: Sir, where is the patience now
That you ſo oft haue boasted to retaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: My teares begin to take his part ſo much,
They marre my counterfetting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: The little dogges, and all;
Trey, Blanch, and Sweet-heart: ſee, they barke at me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Tom, will throw his head at them: Auaunt you
Curres, be thy mouth or blacke or white:
Tooth that poysons if it bite:
Mastiffe, Grey-hound, Mongrill, Grim,
Hound or Spaniell, Brache, or Hym:
Or Bobtaile tight, or Troudle taile,
Tom will make him weepe and waile,
For with throwing thus my head;
Dogs leapt the hatch, and all are fled.
Do, de, de, de: ſese: Come, march to Wakes and Fayres,
And Market Townes: poore Tom thy horne is dry,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Then let them Anatomize Regan: See what breeds about her heart. Is there any cause in Nature that make these hard-hearts. You ſir, I entertaine for one of my hundred; only, I do not like the fashion of your gar-ments. You will ſay they are Persian; but let them bee chang’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Now good my Lord, lye heere, and rest awhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Make no noise, make no noise, draw the Cur-taines: ſo, ſo, wee'l go to Supper i'th’ morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foole.
SPEECH.LINE: And Ile go to bed at noone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither Friend:
Where is the King my Master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Here Sir, but trouble him not, his wits are gon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Good friend, I prythee take him in thy armes;
I haue ore-heard a plot of death vpon him:
There is a Litter ready, lay him in't,
And driue toward Douer friend, where thou ſhalt meete
Both welcome, and protection. Take vp thy Master,
If thou ſhould'st dally halfe an houre, his life
With thine, and all that offer to defend him,
Stand in aſſured loſſe. Take vp, take vp,
And follow me, that will to ſome prouision
Giue thee quicke conduct. Come, come, away.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Cornwall, Regan, Gonerill, Bastard, and Seruants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Poste ſpeedily to my Lord your husband, ſhew him this Letter, the Army of France is landed: ſeeke out the Traitor Glouster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang him instantly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Plucke out his eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Leaue him to my displeasure. Edmond, keepe you our Sister company: the reuenges wee are bound to take vppon your Traitorous Father, are not fit for your beholding. Aduice the Duke where you are going, to a mo’t festinate preparation: we are bound to the like. Our Postes ſhall be ſwift, and intelligent betwixt vs. Fare-well deere Sister, farewell my Lord of Glouster. Enter Steward. How now? Where's the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord of Glouster hath conuey’d him hence
Some fiue or ſix and thirty of his Knights
Hot Questrists after him, met him at gate,
Who, with ſome other of the Lords, dependants,
Are gone with him toward Douer; where they boast
To haue well armed Friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Get horses for your Mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell ſweet Lord, and Sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Edmund farewell: go ſeek the Traitor Gloster,
Pinnion him like a Theefe, bring him before vs:
Though well we may not paſſe vpon his life
Without the forme of Iustice: yet our power
Shall do a curt'sie to our wrath, which men
May blame, but not comptroll.
Who's there? the Traitor?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Ingratefull Fox, ‘tis he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Binde fast his corky armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanes your Graces?
Good my Friends consider you are my Ghests:
Do me no foule play, Friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Binde him I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Hard, hard: O filthy Traitor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnmercifull Lady, as you are, I'me none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: To this Chaire binde him,
Villaine, thou ſhalt finde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: By the kinde Gods, ‘tis mo’t ignobly done
To plucke me by the Beard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: So white, and ſuch a Traitor?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Naughty Ladie,
These haires which thou dost rauish from my chin
Will quicken and accuse thee. I am your Host,
With Robbers hands, my hospitable fauours
You ſhould not ruffle thus. What will you do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Sir.
What Letters had you late from France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Be ſimple anſwer’d, for we know the truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: And what confederacie haue you with the Trai-tors, late footed in the Kingdome?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: To whose hands
You haue ſent the Lunaticke King: Speake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a Letter gueſſingly ſet downe
Which came from one that’s of a newtrall heart,
And not from one oppos’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Cunning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: And false.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Where hast thou ſent the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: To Douer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore to Douer?
Was't thou not charg’d at perill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore to Douer? Let him anſwer that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: I am tyed to'th’ Stake,
And I must ſtand the Course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore to Douer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Because I would not ſee thy cruell Nailes
Plucke out his poore old eyes: nor thy fierce Sister,
In his Annointed flesh, ſticke boarish phangs.
The Sea, with ſuch a ſtorme as his bare head,
In Hell-blacke-night indur’d, would haue buoy’d vp
And quench’d the Stelled fires:
Yet poore old heart, he holpe the Heauens to raine.
If Wolues had at thy Gate howl’d that ſterne time,
Thou ſhould'st haue ſaid, good Porter turne the Key:
All Cruels else ſubscribe: but I ſhall ſee
The winged Vengeance ouertake ſuch Children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: See't ſhalt thou neuer. Fellowes hold y Chaire,
Vpon these eyes of thine, Ile ſet my foote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: He that will thinke to liue, till he be old,
Giue me ſome helpe. — O cruell! O you Gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: One ſide will mocke another: Th’ other too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: If you ſee vengeance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seru.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold your hand, my Lord:
I haue ſeru’d you euer ſince I was a Childe:
But better ſeruice haue I neuer done you,
Then now to bid you hold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, you dogge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: If you did weare a beard vpon your chin,
I'ld ſhake it on this quarrell. What do you meane?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: My Villaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seru.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then come on, and take the chance of anger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me thy Sword. A pezant ſtand vp thus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh I am ſlaine: my Lord, you haue one eye left
To ſee ſome mischefe on him. Oh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: Lest it ſee more, preuent it; Out vilde gelly:
Where is thy luster now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: All darke and comfortleſſe?
Where's my Sonne Edmund?
Edmund, enkindle all the ſparkes of Nature
To quit this horrid acte.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Out treacherous Villaine,
Thou call'st on him, that hates thee. It was he
That made the ouerture of thy Treasons to vs:
Who is too good to pitty thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: O my Follies! then Edgar was abus’d,
Kinde Gods, forgiue me that, and prosper him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him ſmell
His way to Douer. Exit with Glouster.
How is't my Lord? How looke you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Corn.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue receiu’d a hurt: Follow me Lady;
Turne out that eyeleſſe Villaine: throw this Slaue
Vpon the Dunghill: Regan, I bleed apace,
Vntimely comes this hurt. Giue me your arme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet better thus, and knowne to be contemn’d,
Then ſtill contemn’d and flatter’d, to be worst:
The lowest, and mo’t deiected thing of Fortune,
Stands ſtill in esperance, liues not in feare:
The lamentable change is from the best,
The worst returnes to laughter. Welcome then,
Thou vnsubstantiall ayre that I embrace:
The Wretch that thou hast blowne vnto the worst,
Owes nothing to thy blasts.
But who comes heere? My Father poorely led?
World, World, O world!
But that thy ſtrange mutations make vs hate thee,
Life would not yeelde to age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: O my good Lord, I haue bene your Tenant,
And your Fathers Tenant, these fourescore yeares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, get thee away: good Friend be gone,
Thy comforts can do me no good at all,
Thee, they may hurt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: You cannot ſee your way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue no way, and therefore want no eyes:
I ſtumbled when I ſaw. Full oft ‘tis ſeene,
Our meanes ſecure vs, and our meere defects
Proue our Commodities. Oh deere Sonne Edgar,
The food of thy abused Fathers wrath:
Might I but liue to ſee thee in my touch,
I'ld ſay I had eyes againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? who's there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: O Gods! Who is't can ſay I am at the worst?
I am worse then ere I was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis poore mad Tom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: And worse I may be yet: the worst is not,
So long as we can ſay this is the worst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: Fellow, where goest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it a Beggar-man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: Madman, and beggar too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: He has ſome reason, else he could not beg.
I'th’ last nights ſtorme, I ſuch a fellow ſaw;
Which made me thinke a Man, a Worme. My Sonne
Came then into my minde, and yet my minde
Was then ſcarse Friends with him.
I haue heard more ſince:
As Flies to wanton Boyes, are we to th’ Gods,
They kill vs for their ſport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſhould this be?
Bad is the Trade that must play Foole to ſorrow,
Ang'ring it ſelfe, and others. Bleſſe thee Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Is that the naked Fellow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: I, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Get thee away: If for my ſake
Thou wilt ore-take vs hence a mile or twaine
I'th’ way toward Douer, do it for ancient loue,
And bring ſome couering for this naked Soule,
Which Ile intreate to leade me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke ſir, he is mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis the times plague,
When Madmen leade the blinde:
Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure:
Aboue the rest, be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oldm.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile bring him the best Parrell that I haue
Come on't what will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrah, naked fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Poore Tom's a cold. I cannot daub it further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: And yet I must:
Bleſſe thy ſweete eyes, they bleede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Know'st thou the way to Douer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Both ſtyle, and gate; Horseway, and foot-path: poore Tom hath bin ſcarr’d out of his good wits. Bleſſe thee good mans ſonne, from the foule Fiend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Here take this purse, y whom the heau'ns plagues
Haue humbled to all ſtrokes: that I am wretched
Makes thee the happier: Heauens deale ſo ſtill:
Let the ſuperfluous, and Lust-dieted man,
That ſlaues your ordinance, that will not ſee
Because he do's not feele, feele your powre quickly:
So distribution ſhould vndoo exceſſe,
And each man haue enough. Dost thou know Douer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: I Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: There is a Cliffe, whose high and bending head
Lookes fearfully in the confined Deepe:
Bring me but to the very brimme of it,
And Ile repayre the misery thou do'st beare
With ſomething rich about me: from that place,
I ſhall no leading neede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me thy arme;
Poore Tom ſhall leade thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome my Lord. I meruell our mild husband
Not met vs on the way. Now, where's your Master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam within, but neuer man ſo chang’d:
I told him of the Army that was Landed:
He ſmil’d at it. I told him you were comming,
His anſwer was, the worse. Of Glosters Treachery,
And of the loyall Seruice of his Sonne
When I inform’d him, then he call’d me Sot,
And told me I had turn’d the wrong ſide out:
What mo’t he ſhould dislike, ſeemes pleasant to him;
What like, offensiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhall you go no further.
It is the Cowish terror of his ſpirit
That dares not vndertake: Hee'l not feele wrongs
Which tye him to an anſwer: our wishes on the way
May proue effects. Backe Edmond to my Brother,
Hasten his Musters, and conduct his powres.
I must change names at home, and giue the Distaffe
Into my Husbands hands. This trustie Seruant
Shall paſſe betweene vs: ere long you are like to heare
(If you dare venture in your owne behalfe)
A Mistreſſes command. Weare this; ſpare ſpeech,
Decline your head. This kiſſe, if it durst ſpeake
Would ſtretch thy Spirits vp into the ayre:
Conceiue, and fare thee well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast
SPEECH.LINE: Yours in the rankes of death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: My mo’t deere Gloster.
Oh, the difference of man, and man,
To thee a Womans ſeruices are due,
My Foole vsurpes my body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, here come's my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue beene worth the whistle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Gonerill,
You are not worth the dust which the rude winde
Blowes in your face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Milke-Liuer’d man,
That bear'st a cheeke for blowes, a head for wrongs,
Who hast not in thy browes an eye-discerning
Thine Honor, from thy ſuffering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: See thy ſelfe diuell:
Proper deformitie ſeemes not in the Fiend
So horrid as in woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh vaine Foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my good Lord, the Duke of Cornwals dead,
Slaine by his Seruant, going to put out
The other eye of Glouster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Glousters eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: A Seruant that he bred, thrill’d with remorse,
Oppos’d against the act: bending his Sword
To his great Master, who, threat-enrag’d
Flew on him, and among'st them fell’d him dead,
But not without that harmefull ſtroke, which ſince
Hath pluckt him after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: This ſhewes you are aboue
You Iustices, that these our neather crimes
So ſpeedily can venge. But (O poore Glouster)
Lost he his other eye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Both, both, my Lord.
This Leter Madam, craues a ſpeedy anſwer:
‘Tis from your Sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: One way I like this well.
But being widdow, and my Glouster with her,
May all the building in my fancie plucke
Vpon my hatefull life. Another way
The Newes is not ſo tart. Ile read, and anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Where was his Sonne,
When they did take his eyes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Come with my Lady hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: He is not heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord, I met him backe againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Knowes he the wickedneſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord: 'twas he inform’d against him
And quit the house on purpose, that their punishment
Might haue the freer course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Glouster, I liue
To thanke thee for the loue thou ſhew’dst the King,
And to reuenge thine eyes. Come hither Friend,
Tell me what more thou know'st.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter with Drum and Colours, Cordelia, Gentlemen, and Souldiours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, ‘tis he: why he was met euen now
As mad as the vext Sea, ſinging alowd.
Crown’d with ranke Fenitar, and furrow weeds,
With Hardokes, Hemlocke, Nettles, Cuckoo flowres,
Darnell, and all the idle weedes that grow
In our ſustaining Corne. A Centery ſend forth;
Search euery Acre in the high-growne field,
And bring him to our eye. What can mans wisedome
In the restoring his bereaued Sense; he that helpes him,
Take all my outward worth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: There is meanes Madam:
Our foster Nurse of Nature, is repose,
The which he lackes: that to prouoke in him
Are many Simples operatiue, whose power
Will close the eye of Anguish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cord.
SPEECH.LINE: All blest Secrets,
All you vnpublish’d Vertues of the earth
Spring with my teares; be aydant, and remediate
In the Goodmans desires: ſeeke, ſeeke for him,
Least his vngouern’d rage, diſſolue the life
That wants the meanes to leade it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Newes Madam,
The Brittish Powres are marching hitherward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis knowne before. Our preparation ſtands
In expectation of them. O deere Father,
It is thy busineſſe that I go about: Therfore great France
My mourning, and importun’d teares hath pittied:
No blowne Ambition doth our Armes incite,
But loue, deere loue, and our ag’d Fathers Rite:
Soone may I heare, and ſee him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: But are my Brothers Powres ſet forth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Himselfe in person there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam with much ado:
Your Sister is the better Souldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Edmund ſpake not with your Lord at home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: No Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: What might import my Sisters Letter to him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not, Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith he is poasted hence on ſerious matter:
It was great ignorance, Glousters eyes being out
To let him liue. Where he arriues, he moues
All hearts against vs: Edmund, I thinke is gone
In pitty of his misery, to dispatch
His nighted life: Moreouer to descry
The ſtrength o'th’ Enemy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I must needs after him, Madam, with my Letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Our troopes ſet forth to morrow, ſtay with vs:
The wayes are dangerous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I may not Madam:
My Lady charg’d my dutie in this busines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhould ſhe write to Edmund?
Might not you transport her purposes by word? Belike,
Some things, I know not what. Ile loue thee much
Let me vnseale the Letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I had rather—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I know your Lady do's not loue her Husband,
I am ſure of that: and at her late being heere,
She gaue ſtrange Eliads, and mo’t ſpeaking lookes
To Noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſpeake in vnderstanding: Y'are: I know't,
Therefore I do aduise you take this note:
My Lord is dead: Edmond, and I haue talk’d,
And more conuenient is he for my hand
Then for your Ladies: You may gather more:
If you do finde him, pray you giue him this;
And when your Mistris heares thus much from you,
I pray desire her call her wisedome to her.
So fare you well:
If you do chance to heare of that blinde Traitor,
Preferment fals on him, that cuts him off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I could meet Madam, I ſhould ſhew
What party I do follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg
SPEECH.LINE: Fare thee well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: When ſhall I come to th’ top of that ſame hill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: You do climbe vp it now. Look how we labor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinkes the ground is eeuen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Horrible ſteepe.
Hearke, do you heare the Sea?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: No truly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then your other Senses grow imperfect
By your eyes anguish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: So may it be indeed.
Me thinkes thy voyce is alter’d, and thou ſpeak'st
In better phrase, and matter then thou did'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Y'are much deceiu’d: In nothing am I chang’d
But in my Garments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinkes y'are better ſpoken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on Sir,
Heere's the place: ſtand ſtill: how fearefull
And dizie ‘tis, to cast ones eyes ſo low,
The Crowes and Choughes, that wing the midway ayre
Shew ſcarse ſo groſſe as Beetles. Halfe way downe
Hangs one that gathers Sampire: dreadfull Trade:
Me thinkes he ſeemes no bigger then his head.
The Fishermen, that walk’d vpon the beach
Appeare like Mice: and yond tall Anchoring Barke,
Diminish’d to her Cocke: her Cocke, a Buoy
Almost too ſmall for ſight. The murmuring Surge,
That on th’ vnnumbred idle Pebble chafes
Cannot be heard ſo high. Ile looke no more,
Least my braine turne, and the deficient ſight
Topple downe headlong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Set me where you ſtand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me your hand:
You are now within a foote of th’ extreme Verge:
For all beneath the Moone would I not leape vpright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Let go my hand:
Heere Friend's another purse: in it, a Iewell
Well worth a poore mans taking. Fayries, and Gods
Prosper it with thee. Go thou further off,
Bid me farewell, and let me heare thee going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Now fare ye well, good Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Why I do trifle thus with his dispaire,
Is done to cure it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: O you mighty Gods!
This world I do renounce, and in your ſights
Shake patiently my great affliction off:
If I could beare it longer, and not fall
To quarrell with your great opposeleſſe willes,
My ſnuffe, and loathed part of Nature ſhould
Burne it ſelfe out. If Edgar liue, O bleſſe him:
Now Fellow, fare thee well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Gone Sir, farewell:
And yet I know not how conceit may rob
The Treasury of life, when life it ſelfe
Yeelds to the Theft. Had he bin where he thought,
By this had thought bin past. Aliue, or dead?
Hoa, you Sir: Friend, heare you Sir, ſpeake:
Thus might he paſſe indeed: yet he reuiues.
What are you Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, and let me dye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Had'st thou beene ought
But Gozemore, Feathers, Ayre,
(So many fathome downe precipitating)
Thou’dst ſhiuer’d like an Egge: but thou do'st breath:
Hast heauy ſubstance, bleed'st not, ſpeak'st, art ſound,
Ten Masts at each, make not the altitude
Which thou hast perpendicularly fell,
Thy life's a Myracle. Speake yet againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: But haue I falne, or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: From the dread Somnet of this Chalkie Bourne
Looke vp a height, the ſhrill-gorg’d Larke ſo farre
Cannot be ſeene, or heard: Do but looke vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, I haue no eyes:
Is wretchedneſſe depriu’d that benefit
To end it ſelfe by death? 'Twas yet ſome comfort,
When misery could beguile the Tyrants rage,
And frustrate his proud will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me your arme.
Vp, ſo: How is't? Feele you your Legges? You ſtand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Too well, too well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: This is aboue all ſtrangeneſſe,
Vpon the crowne o'th’ Cliffe. What thing was that
Which parted from you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: A poore vnfortunate Beggar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: As I ſtood heere below, me thought his eyes
Were two full Moones: he had a thousand Noses,
Hornes wealk’d, and waued like the enraged Sea:
It was ſome Fiend: Therefore thou happy Father,
Thinke that the cleerest Gods, who make them Honors
Of mens Impoſſibilities, haue preserued thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: I do remember now: henceforth Ile beare
Affliction, till it do cry out it ſelfe
Enough, enough, and dye. That thing you ſpeake of,
I tooke it for a man: often 'twould ſay
The Fiend, the Fiend, he led me to that place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edgar.
SPEECH.LINE: Beare free and patient thoughts.
But who comes heere?
The ſafer ſense will ne're accommodate
His Master thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No, they cannot touch me for crying. I am the
King himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: O thou ſide-piercing ſight!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Nature's aboue Art, in that respect. Ther's your Preſſe-money. That fellow handles his bow, like a Crow-keeper: draw mee a Cloathiers yard. Looke, looke, a Mouse: peace, peace, this peece of toasted Cheese will doo't. There's my Gauntlet, Ile proue it on a Gyant. Bring vp the browne Billes. O well flowne Bird: i'th’ clout, i'th’ clout: Hewgh. Giue the word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Mariorum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Paſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: I know that voice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha! Gonerill with a white beard? They flatter’d me like a Dogge, and told mee I had the white hayres in my Beard, ere the blacke ones were there. To ſay I, and no, to euery thing that I ſaid: I, and no too, was no good Diuinity. When the raine came to wet me once, and the winde to make me chatter: when the Thunder would not peace at my bidding, there I found 'em, there I ſmelt 'em out. Go too, they are not men o'their words; they told me, I was euery thing: ‘Tis a Lye, I am not Agu-proofe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: The tricke of that voyce, I do well remember:
Is't not the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: I, euery inch a King. When I do ſtare, ſee how the Subiect quakes. I pardon that mans life. What was thy cause? Adultery? thou ſhalt not dye: dye for Adultery? No, the Wren goes too't, and the ſmall gilded Fly Do's letcher in my ſight. Let Copulation thriue: For Glousters bastard Son was kinder to his Father, Then my Daughters got 'tweene the lawfull ſheets. Too't Luxury pell-mell, for I lacke Souldiers. Behold yond ſimpring Dame, whose face betweene her Forkes presages Snow; that minces Vertue, & do's ſhake the head to heare of pleasures name. The Fitchew, nor the ſoyled Horse goes too't with a more riotous appe-tite: Downe from the waste they are Centaures, though Women all aboue: but to the Girdle do the Gods inhe-rit, beneath is all the Fiends. There's hell, there's darke-nes, there is the ſulphurous pit; burning, ſcalding, ſtench, consumption: Fye, fie, fie; pah, pah: Giue me an Ounce of Ciuet; good Apothecary ſweeten my immagination: There's money for thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: O let me kiſſe that hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me wipe it first,
It ſmelles of Mortality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: O ruin’d peece of Nature, this great world
Shall ſo weare out to naught.
Do'st thou know me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: I remember thine eyes well enough: dost thou ſquiny at me? No, doe thy worst blinde Cupid, Ile not loue. Reade thou this challenge, marke but the penning of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Were all thy Letters Sunnes, I could not ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: I would not take this from report,
It is, and my heart breakes at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Read.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: What with the Case of eyes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ho, are you there with me? No eies in your head, nor no mony in your purse? Your eyes are in a hea-uy case, your purse in a light, yet you ſee how this world goes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee it feelingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: What, art mad? A man may ſee how this world goes, with no eyes. Looke with thine eares: See how yond Iustice railes vpon yond ſimple theefe. Hearke in thine eare: Change places, and handy-dandy, which is the Iustice, which is the theefe: Thou hast ſeene a Far-mers dogge barke at a Beggar?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: And the Creature run from the Cur: there thou might'st behold the great image of Authoritie, a Dogg's obey’d in Office. Thou, Rascall Beadle, hold thy bloody hand: why dost thou lash that Whore? Strip thy owne backe, thou hotly lusts to vse her in that kind, for which thou whip'st her. The Vsurer hangs the Cozener. Tho-rough tatter’d cloathes great Vices do appeare: Robes, and Furr’d gownes hide all. Place ſinnes with Gold, and the ſtrong Lance of Iustice, hurtleſſe breakes: Arme it in ragges, a Pigmies ſtraw do's pierce it. None do's offend, none, I ſay none, Ile able 'em; take that of me my Friend, who haue the power to ſeale th’ accusers lips. Get thee glaſſe-eyes, and like a ſcuruy Politician, ſeeme to ſee the things thou dost not. Now, now, now, now. Pull off my Bootes: harder, harder, ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: O matter, and impertinency mixt,
Reason in Madneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou wilt weepe my Fortunes, take my eyes.
I know thee well enough, thy name is Glouster:
Thou must be patient; we came crying hither:
Thou know'st, the first time that we ſmell the Ayre
We wawle, and cry. I will preach to thee: Marke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, alacke the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: When we are borne, we cry that we are come
To this great ſtage of Fooles. This a good blocke:
It were a delicate ſtratagem to ſhoo
A Troope of Horse with Felt: Ile put't in proofe,
And when I haue ſtolne vpon these Son in Lawes,
Then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heere he is: lay hand vpon him, Sir.
Your mo’t deere Daughter—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No rescue? What, a Prisoner? I am euen
The Naturall Foole of Fortune. Vse me well,
You ſhall haue ransome. Let me haue Surgeons,
I am cut to'th’ Braines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall haue any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No Seconds? All my ſelfe?
Why, this would make a man, a man of Salt
To vse his eyes for Garden water-pots. I wil die brauely,
Like a ſmugge Bridegroome. What? I will be Iouiall:
Come, come, I am a King, Masters, know you that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a Royall one, and we obey you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Then there's life in't. Come, and you get it,
You ſhall get it by running: Sa, ſa, ſa, ſa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſight mo’t pittifull in the meanest wretch,
Past ſpeaking of in a King. Thou hast a Daughter
Who redeemes Nature from the generall curse
Which twaine haue brought her to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Haile gentle Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ſpeed you: what’s your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you heare ought (Sir) of a Battell toward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t ſure, and vulgar:
Euery one heares that, which can distinguish ſound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: But by your fauour:
How neere's the other Army?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Neere, and on ſpeedy foot: the maine descry
Stands on the hourely thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you Sir, that’s all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Though that the Queen on ſpecial cause is here
Her Army is mou’d on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: You euer gentle Gods, take my breath from me,
Let not my worser Spirit tempt me againe
To dye before you please.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Well pray you Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Now good ſir, what are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: A mo’t poore man, made tame to Fortunes blows
Who, by the Art of knowne, and feeling ſorrowes,
Am pregnant to good pitty. Giue me your hand,
Ile leade you to ſome biding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Heartie thankes:
The bountie, and the benizon of Heauen
To boot, and boot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: A proclaim’d prize: mo’t happie
That eyeleſſe head of thine, was first fram’d flesh
To raise my fortunes. Thou old, vnhappy Traitor,
Breefely thy ſelfe remember: the Sword is out
That must destroy thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: Now let thy friendly hand
Put ſtrength enough too't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore, bold Pezant,
Dar'st thou ſupport a publish’d Traitor? Hence,
Least that th’ infection of his fortune take
Like hold on thee. Let go his arme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Chill not let go Zir,
Without vurther 'casion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Let go Slaue, or thou dy'st.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Gentleman goe your gate, and let poore volke paſſe: and 'chud ha' bin zwaggerd out of my life, 'twould not ha' bin zo long as ‘tis, by a vortnight. Nay, come not neere th’ old man: keepe out che vor' ye, or Ile try whither your Costard, or my Ballow be the harder; chill be plaine with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Out Dunghill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Chill picke your teeth Zir: come, no matter vor your foynes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Slaue thou hast ſlaine me: Villain, take my purse;
If euer thou wilt thriue, bury my bodie,
And giue the Letters which thou find'st about me,
To Edmund Earle of Glouster: ſeeke him out
Vpon the English party. Oh vntimely death, death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: I know thee well. A ſeruiceable Villaine,
As duteous to the vices of thy Mistris,
As badneſſe would desire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: What, is he dead?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Sit you downe Father: rest you. Let's ſee these Pockets; the Letters that he ſpeakes of May be my Friends: hee's dead; I am onely ſorry He had no other Deathsman. Let vs ſee: Leaue gentle waxe, and manners: blame vs not To know our enemies mindes, we rip their hearts, Their Papers is more lawfull. Reads the Letter. Let our reciprocall vowes be remembred. You haue manie opportunities to cut him off: if your will want not, time and place will be fruitfully offer’d. There is nothing done. If hee returne the Conqueror, then am I the Prisoner, and his bed, my Gaole, from the loathed warmth whereof, deliuer me, and ſup-ply the place for your Labour. Your (Wife, ſo I would ſay) affectio-nate Seruant. Gonerill. Oh indistinguish’d ſpace of Womans will, A plot vpon her vertuous Husbands life, And the exchange my Brother: heere, in the ſands Thee Ile rake vp, the poste vnsanctified Of murtherous Letchers: and in the mature time, With this vngracious paper ſtrike the ſight Of the death-practis’d Duke: for him ‘tis well, That of thy death, and busineſſe, I can tell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glou.
SPEECH.LINE: The King is mad:
How ſtiffe is my vilde ſense
That I ſtand vp, and haue ingenious feeling
Of my huge Sorrowes? Better I were distract,
So ſhould my thoughts be ſeuer’d from my greefes,
And wœs, by wrong imaginations loose
The knowledge of themselues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me your hand:
Farre off methinkes I heare the beaten Drumme.
Come Father, Ile bestow you with a Friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: O thou good Kent,
How ſhall I liue and worke
To match thy goodneſſe?
My life will be too ſhort,
And euery measure faile me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: To be acknowledg’d Madam is ore-pai’d,
All my reports go with the modest truth,
Nor more, nor clipt, but ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Be better ſuited,
These weedes are memories of those worser houres:
I prythee put them off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon deere Madam,
Yet to be knowne ſhortens my made intent,
My boone I make it, that you know me not,
Till time, and I, thinke meet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Then be't ſo my good Lord:
How do's the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam ſleepes ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: O you kind Gods!
Cure this great breach in his abused Nature,
Th’ vntun’d and iarring ſenses, O winde vp,
Of this childe-changed Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: So please your Maiesty,
That we may wake the King, he hath ſlept long?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Be gouern’d by your knowledge, and proceede
I'th’ ſway of your owne will: is he array’d?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Lear in a chaire carried by Seruants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam: in the heauineſſe of ſleepe,
We put fresh garments on him.
Be by good Madam when we do awake him,
I doubt of his Temperance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: O my deere Father, restauratian hang
Thy medicine on my lippes, and let this kiſſe
Repaire those violent harmes, that my two Sisters
Haue in thy Reuerence made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Kind and deere Princeſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Had you not bin their Father, these white flakes
Did challenge pitty of them. Was this a face
To be oppos’d against the iarring windes?
Mine Enemies dogge, though he had bit me,
Should haue ſtood that night against my fire,
And was't thou faine (poore Father)
To houell thee with Swine and Rogues forlorne,
In ſhort, and musty ſtraw? Alacke, alacke,
‘Tis wonder that thy life and wits, at once
Had not concluded all. He wakes, ſpeake to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam do you, ‘tis fittest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: How does my Royall Lord?
How fares your Maiesty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: You do me wrong to take me out o'th’ graue,
Thou art a Soule in bliſſe, but I am bound
Vpon a wheele of fire, that mine owne teares
Do ſcal’d, like molten Lead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, do you know me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a ſpirit I know, where did you dye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Still, ſtill, farre wide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: He's ſcarse awake,
Let him alone a while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Where haue I bin?
Where am I? Faire day light?
I am mightily abus’d; I ſhould eu'n dye with pitty
To ſee another thus. I know not what to ſay:
I will not ſweare these are my hands: let's ſee,
I feele this pin pricke, would I were aſſur’d
Of my condition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: O looke vpon me Sir,
And hold your hand in benediction o’re me,
You must not kneele.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray do not mocke me:
I am a very foolish fond old man,
Fourescore and vpward,
Not an houre more, nor leſſe:
And to deale plainely,
I feare I am not in my perfect mind.
Me thinkes I ſhould know you, and know this man,
Yet I am doubtfull: For I am mainely ignorant
What place this is: and all the ſkill I haue
Remembers not these garments: nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me,
For (as I am a man) I thinke this Lady
To be my childe Cordelia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo I am: I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Be your teares wet?
Yes faith: I pray weepe not,
If you haue poyson for me, I will drinke it:
I know you do not loue me, for your Sisters
Haue (as I do remember) done me wrong.
You haue ſome cause, they haue not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: No cause, no cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I in France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: In your owne kingdome Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not abuse me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Be comforted good Madam, the great rage
You ſee is kill’d in him: desire him to go in,
Trouble him no more till further ſetling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt please your Highneſſe walke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: You must beare with me:
Pray you now forget, and forgiue,
I am old and foolish.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter with Drumme and Colours, Edmund, Regan. Gentlemen, and Souldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold,
Or whether ſince he is aduis’d by ought
To change the course, he's full of alteration,
And ſelfereprouing, bring his constant pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Our Sisters man is certainely miscarried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis to be doubted Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Now ſweet Lord,
You know the goodneſſe I intend vpon you:
Tell me but truly, but then ſpeake the truth,
Do you not loue my Sister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: In honour’d Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: But haue you neuer found my Brothers way,
To the fore-fended place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: No by mine honour, Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer ſhall endure her, deere my Lord
Be not familiar with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare not, ſhe and the Duke her husband.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter with Drum and Colours, Albany, Gonerill, Soldiers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Our very louing Sister, well be-met:
Sir, this I heard, the King is come to his Daughter
With others, whom the rigour of our State
Forc’d to cry out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Regan.
SPEECH.LINE: Why is this reasond?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gone.
SPEECH.LINE: Combine together 'gainst the Enemie:
For these domesticke and particular broiles,
Are not the question heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's then determine with th’ ancient of warre
On our proceeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Sister you'le go with vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis mo’t conuenient, pray go with vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ho, I know the Riddle, I will goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: If ere your Grace had ſpeech with man ſo poore,
Heare me one word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ouertake you, ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Before you fight the Battaile, ope this Letter:
If you haue victory, let the Trumpet ſound
For him that brought it: wretched though I ſeeme,
I can produce a Champion, that will proue
What is auouched there. If you miscarry,
Your busineſſe of the world hath ſo an end,
And machination ceases. Fortune loues you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay till I haue read the Letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: I was forbid it:
When time ſhall ſerue, let but the Herald cry,
And Ile appeare againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Why farethee well, I will o’re-looke thy paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: The Enemy's in view, draw vp your powers,
Heere is the gueſſe of their true ſtrength and Forces,
By dilligent discouerie, but your hast
Is now vrg’d on you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb
SPEECH.LINE: We will greet the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: To both these Sisters haue I ſworne my loue:
Each iealous of the other, as the ſtung
Are of the Adder. Which of them ſhall I take?
Both? One? Or neither? Neither can be enioy’d
If both remaine aliue: To take the Widdow,
Exasperates, makes mad her Sister Gonerill,
And hardly ſhall I carry out my ſide,
Her husband being aliue. Now then, wee'l vse
His countenance for the Battaile, which being done,
Let her who would be rid of him, deuise
His ſpeedy taking off. As for the mercie
Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia,
The Battaile done, and they within our power,
Shall neuer ſee his pardon: for my ſtate,
Stands on me to defend, not to debate.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum within. Enter with Drumme and Colours, Lear, Cordelia, and Souldiers, ouer the Stage, and Exeunt. Enter Edgar, and Gloster

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere Father, take the ſhadow of this Tree
For your good hoast: pray that the right may thriue:
If euer I returne to you againe,
Ile bring you comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo
SPEECH.LINE: Grace go with you Sir.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Alarum and Retreat within. Enter Edgar

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edgar.
SPEECH.LINE: Away old man, giue me thy hand, away:
King Lear hath lost, he and his Daughter tane,
Giue me thy hand: Come on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo.
SPEECH.LINE: No further Sir, a man may rot euen heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: What in ill thoughts againe?
Men must endure
Their going hence, euen as their comming hither,
Ripeneſſe is all come on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Glo
SPEECH.LINE: And that’s true too.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter in conquest with Drum and Colours, Edmund, Lear, and Cordelia, as prisoners, Souldiers, Captaine

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Some Officers take them away: good guard,
Vntill their greater pleasures first be knowne
That are to censure them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cor.
SPEECH.LINE: We are not the first,
Who with best meaning haue incurr’d the worst:
For thee oppreſſed King I am cast downe,
My ſelfe could else out-frowne false Fortunes frowne.
Shall we not ſee these Daughters, and these Sisters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, no, no: come let's away to prison,
We two alone will ſing like Birds i'th’ Cage:
When thou dost aske me bleſſing, Ile kneele downe
And aske of thee forgiueneſſe: So wee'l liue,
And pray, and ſing, and tell old tales, and laugh
At gilded Butterflies: and heere (poore Rogues)
Talke of Court newes, and wee'l talke with them too,
Who looses, and who wins; who's in, who's out;
And take vpon's the mystery of things,
As if we were Gods ſpies: And wee'l weare out
In a wall’d prison, packs and ſects of great ones,
That ebbe and flow by th’ Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Take them away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon ſuch ſacrifices my Cordelia,
The Gods themselues throw Incense.
Haue I caught thee?
He that parts vs, ſhall bring a Brand from Heauen,
And fire vs hence, like Foxes: wipe thine eyes,
The good yeares ſhall deuoure them, flesh and fell,
Ere they ſhall make vs weepe?
Weele ſee 'em ſtaru’d first: come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither Captaine, hearke.
Take thou this note, go follow them to prison,
One ſtep I haue aduanc’d thee, if thou do'st
As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way
To Noble Fortunes: know thou this, that men
Are as the time is; to be tender minded
Do's not become a Sword, thy great imployment
Will not beare question: either ſay thou'lt do't,
Or thriue by other meanes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Capt.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile do't my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: About it, and write happy, when th’hast done,
Marke I ſay instantly, and carry it ſo
As I haue ſet it downe. Exit Captaine.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flourish. Enter Albany, Gonerill, Regan, Soldiers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, you haue ſhew’d to day your valiant ſtraine
And Fortune led you well: you haue the Captiues
Who were the opposites of this dayes ſtrife:
I do require them of you ſo to vse them,
As we ſhall find their merites, and our ſafety
May equally determine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I thought it fit,
To ſend the old and miserable King to ſome retention,
Whose age had Charmes in it, whose Title more,
To plucke the common bosome on his ſide,
And turne our imprest Launces in our eies
Which do command them. With him I ſent the Queen:
My reason all the ſame, and they are ready
To morrow, or at further ſpace, t’ appeare
Where you ſhall hold your Seſſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, by your patience,
I hold you but a ſubiect of this Warre,
Not as a Brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: That's as we list to grace him.
Methinkes our pleasure might haue bin demanded
Ere you had ſpoke ſo farre. He led our Powers,
Bore the Commiſſion of my place and person,
The which immediacie may well ſtand vp,
And call it ſelfe your Brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo hot:
In his owne grace he doth exalt himselfe,
More then in your addition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: In my rights,
By me inuested, he compeeres the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: That were the mo’t, if he ſhould husband you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Iesters do oft proue Prophets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Hola, hola,
That eye that told you ſo, look’d but a ſquint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rega.
SPEECH.LINE: Lady I am not well, else I ſhould answere
From a full flowing ſtomack. Generall,
Take thou my Souldiers, prisoners, patrimony,
Dispose of them, of me, the walls is thine:
Witneſſe the world, that I create thee heere
My Lord, and Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Meane you to enioy him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: The let alone lies not in your good will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor in thine Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Halfe-blooded fellow, yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Let the Drum ſtrike, and proue my title thine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay yet, heare reason: Edmund, I arrest thee
On capitall Treason; and in thy arrest,
This guilded Serpent: for your claime faire Sisters,
I bare it in the interest of my wife,
‘Tis ſhe is ſub-contracted to this Lord,
And I her husband contradict your Banes.
If you will marry, make your loues to me,
My Lady is bespoke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: An enterlude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art armed Gloster,
Let the Trumpet ſound:
If none appeare to proue vpon thy person,
Thy heynous, manifest, and many Treasons,
There is my pledge: Ile make it on thy heart
Ere I taste bread, thou art in nothing leſſe
Then I haue heere proclaim’d thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reg.
SPEECH.LINE: Sicke, O ſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: If not, Ile nere trust medicine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: There's my exchange, what in the world hes
That names me Traitor, villain-like he lies,
Call by the Trumpet: he that dares approach;
On him, on you, who not, I will maintaine
My truth and honor firmely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: A Herald, ho.
Trust to thy ſingle vertue, for thy Souldiers
All leuied in my name, haue in my name
Tooke their discharge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Regan.
SPEECH.LINE: My ſickneſſe growes vpon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: She is not well, conuey her to my Tent. Come hither Herald, let the Trumpet ſound, And read out this. A Trumpet ſounds.] [Herald reads. If any man of qualitie or degree, within the lists of the Ar-my, will maintaine vpon Edmund, ſupposed Earle of Gloster, that he is a manifold Traitor, let him appeare by the third ſound of the Trumpet: he is bold in his defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Her
SPEECH.LINE: Againe. 2 Trumpet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Her
SPEECH.LINE: Againe. 3 Trumpet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Aske him his purposes, why he appeares
Vpon this Call o'th’ Trumpet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Her.
SPEECH.LINE: What are you?
Your name, your quality, and why you anſwer
This present Summons?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Know my name is lost
By Treasons tooth: bare-gnawne, and Canker-bit,
Yet am I Noble as the Aduersary
I come to cope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is that Aduersary?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: What's he that ſpeakes for Edmund Earle of Gloster?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Himselfe, what ſaist thou to him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Draw thy Sword,
That if my ſpeech offend a Noble heart,
Thy arme may do thee Iustice, heere is mine:
Behold it is my priuiledge,
The priuiledge of mine Honours,
My oath, and my profeſſion. I protest,
Maugre thy ſtrength, place, youth, and eminence,
Despise thy victor-Sword, and fire new Fortune,
Thy valor, and thy heart, thou art a Traitor:
False to thy Gods, thy Brother, and thy Father,
Conspirant 'gainst this high illustrious Prince,
And from th’ extremest vpward of thy head,
To the discent and dust below thy foote,
A mo’t Toad-spotted Traitor. Say thou no,
This Sword, this arme, and my best ſpirits are bent
To proue vpon thy heart, where to I ſpeake,
Thou lyest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: In wisedome I ſhould aske thy name,
But ſince thy out-side lookes ſo faire and Warlike,
And that thy tongue (some ſay) of breeding breathes,
What ſafe, and nicely I might well delay,
By rule of Knight-hood, I disdaine and ſpurne:
Backe do I toſſe these Treasons to thy head,
With the hell-hated Lye, ore-whelme thy heart,
Which for they yet glance by, and ſcarcely bruise,
This Sword of mine ſhall giue them instant way,
Where they ſhall rest for euer. Trumpets ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb
SPEECH.LINE: Saue him, ſaue him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: This is practise Gloster,
By th’ law of Warre, thou wast not bound to anſwer
An vnknowne opposite: thou art not vanquish’d,
But cozend, and beguild.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Shut your mouth Dame,
Or with this paper ſhall I ſtop it: hold Sir,
Thou worse then any name, reade thine owne euill:
No tearing Lady, I perceiue you know it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Say if I do, the Lawes are mine not thine,
Who can araigne me for't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t monstrous! O, know'st thou this paper?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Aske me not what I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Go after her, ſhe's desperate, gouerne her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: What you haue charg’d me with,
That haue I done,
And more, much more, the time will bring it out.
‘Tis past, and ſo am I: But what art thou
That hast this Fortune on me? If thou'rt Noble,
I do forgiue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's exchange charity:
I am no leſſe in blood then thou art Edmond,
If more, the more th’hast wrong’d me.
My name is Edgar and thy Fathers Sonne,
The Gods are iust, and of our pleasant vices
Make instruments to plague vs:
The darke and vitious place where thee he got,
Cost him his eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Th'hast ſpoken right, ‘tis true,
The Wheele is come full circle, I am heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thought thy very gate did prophesie
A Royall Nobleneſſe: I must embrace thee,
Let ſorrow ſplit my heart, if euer I
Did hate thee, or thy Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy Prince I know't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Where haue you hid your ſelfe?
How haue you knowne the miseries of your Father?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: By nursing them my Lord. List a breefe tale,
And when ‘tis told, O that my heart would burst.
The bloody proclamation to escape
That follow’d me ſo neere, (O our liues ſweetneſſe,
That we the paine of death would hourely dye,
Rather then die at once) taught me to ſhift
Into a mad-mans rags, t’ aſſume a ſemblance
That very Dogges disdain’d: and in this habit
Met I my Father with his bleeding Rings,
Their precious Stones new lost: became his guide,
Led him, begg’d for him, ſau’d him from dispaire.
Neuer (O fault) reueal’d my ſelfe vnto him,
Vntill ſome halfe houre past when I was arm’d,
Not ſure, though hoping of this good ſucceſſe,
I ask’d his bleſſing, and from first to last
Told him our pilgrimage. But his flaw’d heart
(Alacke too weake the conflict to ſupport)
Twixt two extremes of paſſion, ioy and greefe,
Burst ſmilingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: This ſpeech of yours hath mou’d me,
And ſhall perchance do good, but ſpeake you on,
You looke as you had ſomething more to ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: If there be more, more wofull, hold it in,
For I am almost ready to diſſolue,
Hearing of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe, helpe: O helpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: What kinde of helpe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanes this bloody Knife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis hot, it ſmoakes, it came euen from the heart of— O ſhe's dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Who dead? Speake man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Lady Sir, your Lady; and her Sister
By her is poyson’d: ſhe confeſſes it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I was contracted to them both, all three
Now marry in an instant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes Kent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Produce the bodies, be they aliue or dead;

LINE.STAGEDIR: Gonerill and Regans bodies brought out.

SPEECH.LINE: This iudgement of the Heauens that makes vs tremble.
Touches vs not with pitty: O, is this he?
The time will not allow the complement
Which very manners vrges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I am come
To bid my King and Master aye good night.
Is he not here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Great thing of vs forgot,
Speake Edmund, where's the King? and where's Cordelia?
Seest thou this obiect Kent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, why thus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet Edmund was belou’d:
The one the other poison’d for my ſake,
And after ſlew herselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo: couer their faces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: I pant for life: ſome good I meane to do
Despight of mine owne Nature. Quickly ſend,
(Be briefe in it) to'th’ Castle, for my Writ
Is on the life of Lear, and on Cordelia:
Nay, ſend in time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Run, run, O run.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: To who my Lord? Who ha's the Office?
Send thy token of repreeue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: Well thought on, take my Sword,
Giue it the Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Hast thee for thy life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bast.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath Commiſſion from thy Wife and me,
To hang Cordelia in the prison, and
To lay the blame vpon her owne dispaire,
That ſhe for-did her ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gods defend her, beare him hence awhile.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Lear with Cordelia in his armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Howle, howle, howle: O you are men of ſtones,
Had I your tongues and eyes, Il’d vse them ſo,
That Heauens vault ſhould crack: ſhe's gone for euer.
I know when one is dead, and when one liues,
She's dead as earth: Lend me a Looking-glaſſe,
If that her breath will mist or ſtaine the ſtone,
Why then ſhe liues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the promis’d end?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Or image of that horror.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Fall and cease.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: This feather ſtirs, ſhe liues: if it be ſo,
It is a chance which do's redeeme all ſorrowes
That euer I haue felt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: O my good Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Prythee away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis Noble Kent your Friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: A plague vpon you Murderors, Traitors all,
I might haue ſau’d her, now ſhe's gone for euer:
Cordelia, Cordelia, ſtay a little. Ha:
What is't thou ſaist? Her voice was euer ſoft,
Gentle, and low, an excellent thing in woman.
I kill’d the Slaue that was a hanging thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true (my Lords) he did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Did I not fellow?
I haue ſeene the day, with my good biting Faulchion
I would haue made him ſkip: I am old now,
And these ſame croſſes ſpoile me. Who are you?
Mine eyes are not o'th’ best, Ile tell you ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: If Fortune brag of two, ſhe lou’d and hated,
One of them we behold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: This is a dull ſight, are you not Kent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſame: your Seruant Kent,
Where is your Seruant Caius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: He's a good fellow, I can tell you that,
He'le ſtrike and quickly too, he's dead and rotten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord, I am the very man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſee that ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: That from your first of difference and decay,
Haue follow’d your ſad ſteps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: You are welcome hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor no man else:
All's cheerleſſe, darke, and deadly,
Your eldest Daughters haue fore-done themselues,
And desperately are dead

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſo I thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: He knowes not what he ſaies, and vaine is it
That we present vs to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Very bootleſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Edmund is dead my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: That's but a trifle heere:
You Lords and Noble Friends, know our intent,
What comfort to this great decay may come,
Shall be appli’d. For vs we will resigne,
During the life of this old Maiesty
To him our absolute power, you to your rights,
With boote, and ſuch addition as your Honours
Haue more then merited. All Friends ſhall
Taste the wages of their vertue, and all Fœs
The cup of their deseruings: O ſee, ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lear.
SPEECH.LINE: And my poore Foole is hang’d: no, no, no life?
Why ſhould a Dog, a Horse, a Rat haue life,
And thou no breath at all? Thou'lt come no more,
Neuer, neuer, neuer, neuer, neuer.
Pray you vndo this Button. Thanke you Sir,
Do you ſee this? Looke on her? Looke her lips,
Looke there, looke there. He dies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: He faints, my Lord, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Breake heart, I prythee breake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke vp my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: Vex not his ghoſt, O let him paſſe, he hates him,
That would vpon the wracke of this tough world
Stretch him out longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: He is gon indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: The wonder is, he hath endur’d ſo long,
He but vsurpt his life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alb.
SPEECH.LINE: Beare them from hence, our present busineſſe
Is generall wœ: Friends of my ſoule, you twaine,
Rule in this Realme, and the gor’d ſtate ſustaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a iourney Sir, ſhortly to go,
My Master calls me, I must not ſay no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edg.
SPEECH.LINE: The waight of this ſad time we must obey,
Speake what we feele, not what we ought to ſay:
The oldest hath borne mo’t, we that are yong,
Shall neuer ſee ſo much, nor liue ſo long.
